An area of low pressure off the mid-Atlantic Coast brought a light to moderate snow to the Berkshires on Wednesday March 9, 2022. Snow amounts ranged anywhere from 3-6 inches. This resulted in some speed reductions across the region, including the Massachusetts Turnpike reducing speeds to 40 mph.||Key Impacts: Speed reductions.

An area of low pressure off the mid-Atlantic Coast brought a light to moderate snow to the Berkshires on Wednesday March 9, 2022. Snow amounts ranged anywhere from 3-6 inches. This resulted in some speed reductions across the region, including the Massachusetts Turnpike reducing speeds to 40 mph.||Key Impacts: Speed reductions.

A winter storm system resulted in a total of 3-8 inches across western Massachusetts on March 12, 2022 with the higher amounts across northern Berkshire County. This system resulted in speed reductions and travel restrictions including a 40 mph speed limit on the Massachusetts Turnpike.||Key Impacts: Travel Restrictions, Speed reductions.

A winter storm system resulted in a total of 3-8 inches across western Massachusetts on March 12, 2022 with the higher amounts across northern Berkshire County. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Fairhaven, lightning struck a home on Main Street, near Woodcock Way. The strike resulted in a fire on the gas line in the basement.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from New York City early in the morning to New Hampshire and Maine by late morning.  A cluster of heavy showers and thunderstorms moved across southeast MA just before daybreak.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In New Bedford, two cars were stuck in flood waters at the intersection of Purchase Street and Deane Street at the railroad underpass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Falmouth at 615 AM EDT (515 AM EST), a trained spotter reported a gust to 57 mph. In Chatham at 513 AM EST, the ASOS at the Chatham Airport (KCQX) recorded a gust to 56 mph. In Provincetown at 522 AM EST, the AWOS at the Provincetown Airport recorded at gust to 56 mph.  In Barnstable at 229 AM EST, the Fire Dept. reported wires down on Main Street.  In Orleans at 354 AM EST, police reported a large limb down on Route 6A.  In Sandwich, between 447 AM EST and 500 AM EST, law enforcement reported a large tree down on Service Road at Tarragon Drive and a tree down on Great Hilll Road near Popple Bottom Road.  In Brewster at 504 AM EST, the Fire Dept. reported a tree down on a detached garage on Gages Way.  In Dennis at 514 AM EST, law enforcement reported a large branch down on Old Chatham Road at Kelley Way.  In Falmouth at 523 AM EST, police reported a large tree down on a house's service wires, but no street name was given.  All of the aforementioned reports were relayed by amateur radio operators.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved northward from the mid-Atlantic coast late on the 18th to interior New England during the pre-dawn morning hours on the 19th.  Locally heavy rainfall helped bring down damaging wind gusts from a low-level jet across Rhode Island and southeast Massachusetts.  The storm system also brought 1 to 4 inches of snow to the east slopes of the Berkshires in northwest Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 345 AM EDT (245 AM EST), a Weatherflow mesonet site at West Island recorded a wind gust to 66 mph.  At 458 AM EDT (358 AM EST), a Weatherflow station at The Knubble at Horseneck Beach in Westport recorded a wind gust to 69 mph.  At 459 AM EDT (359 AM EST), the ASOS at the New Bedford Airport (KBED) recorded a gust to 52 mph.  The following reports were from law enforcement, relayed via amateur radio operators. They all occurred between 413 AM and 628 AM EDT (313 AM and 528 AM EST).  In Westport, multiple small branches were down on the entire length of Old Harbor Road; power lines were down on Pine Hill Road; and a tree and wires were down on Tickle Road.  In Somerset, a tree and power lines were down on Hargraves Avenue.  In New Bedford, a tree was down on Reed Road at Stonewall Avenue; a large tree branch was down on Acushnet Avenue; and a tree and wires were down on a car on Bullard Street.  In Fall River, a large tree was down on the southbound lane of Plymouth Avenue; the fire department reported a tree down on wires on an unspecified street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved northward from the mid-Atlantic coast late on the 18th to interior New England during the pre-dawn morning hours on the 19th.  Locally heavy rainfall helped bring down damaging wind gusts from a low-level jet across Rhode Island and southeast Massachusetts.  The storm system also brought 1 to 4 inches of snow to the east slopes of the Berkshires in northwest Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds generally were gusting to around 50 mph.  In Boston at 454 AM EDT (354 AM EST), the ASOS at Logan International Airport (KBOS) recorded a gust to 46 mph.  In Boston at 359 AM EDT (259 AM EST), police reported a tree down on a car on Camden Street (relayed by amateur radio).

At 500 AM EDT (400 AM EST), the ASOS at Plymouth Airport (KPYM) recorded a gust to 55 mph.  At 555 AM EDT (455 AM EST), the AWOS at Marshfield Airport (KGHG) recorded a gust to 48 mph.  At 529 AM EDT (429 AM EST), the Duxbury Fire Dept. reported a tree and wires down on West Street (report relayed by amateur radio).

The aforementioned reports were from law enforcement, relayed by amateur radio operators.

In Lakeville at 502 AM EDT (402 AM EST), high tension power lines were down on Pickens Street near Precinct Street.  In Middleborough between 556 AM EDT (456 AM EST) and 621 AM EDT (521 AM EST), law enforcement reported a tree and wires down on Fuller Street and a tree down on Marion Road between Stony Point Road and Long Point Road. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the Florence section of Northampton, a 50 foot by 50 foot wooden permanent pavilion structure was blown crooked at a landmark restaurant/tavern. The footings, which were lifted and bent, were attached by a metal bracket to concrete.  The pavilion can accomodate 18 tables with 4 people per table.  The building inspector classified the damage as $20,000.  Slightly farther to the southeast, a 50 ft by 75 ft. section of roofing, including insulation and rubber membrane, was peeled off of the Smith Vocational and Agricultural High School.  There was little in the way of water damage inside the school.  The Northampton building inspector rated the roof damage as $30,000.  Still farther to the southeast, a tree was down on Washington Avenue, as reported by amateur radio.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough caused isolated thunderstorms to form in eastern Massachusetts during the late afternoon. But a scattered line of severe thunderstorms impacted western and central Massachusetts during the evening, in association with an approaching cold front.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front moved through southern New England and triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms.  A lightning strike caused minor damage in northeast Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Dudley, a tree and wires were down due to lightning, per the fire department, via amateur radio.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moving eastward from the eastern Great Lakes, triggered strong thunderstorms in New York state, which moved into southern New England overnight.  The atmosphere was very unstable and surface dewpoints were near 70 degrees. The result was strong to locally severe thunderstorms before daybreak in southeast MA.  Sunshine boosted temperatures in the afternoon, then a cold front swept through in the evening hours, triggering a second round of strong to severe thunderstorms, mainly in western and central MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed power lines and half inch diameter hail was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms ahead of an approaching cold front resulted in multiple wind damage reports across western Massachusetts during the afternoon and evening hours on Tuesday July 12, 2022. A NWS Storm Survey concluded an area of straight line wind damage with estimated wind speeds of 85 mph occurred across the Town of Lenox. There was one fatality reported just south of Lenox (Berkshire County) due to a large tree falling onto a pickup truck.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lenox Police reported that a 56 year old man was killed when a large tree came down in the travel line onto his pickup truck at the intersection of Route 7 and Old Stockbridge Road. Report was obtained via a local newspaper.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS Storm Survey confirmed straight line wind damage in the Town of Lenox. Damage was sporadic and ranged from broken tree limbs to large diameter trees snapped and uprooted. Damage was most concentrated downwind of large open spaces or lakes. Downed trees blocked many roads and caused numerous power outages. Trees also fell onto homes and cars. Some festival tents were also blown away. The maximum estimated winds were 85 mph with a path length of 1.7 miles and width of 0.8 of a mile.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Huntington, trees were down on Mountain View.  Report relayed by amateur radio.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level short wave trough moving through northern New England combined with an advancing cold front to produce severe thunderstorms in the late afternoon and evening hours.  Despite low K Indices and dry air aloft, the storms managed to strengthen and the dry air helped enhance the severe wind gusts.  The storms mainly impacted areas from western MA east-southeastward into northern CT and northern RI.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Montague, in the Millers Falls portion of town, a large tree was down on a house and a car on the 800 block of Wendell Road.  Trees were also downed on the 900 block of Wendell Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough of low pressure in western New England combined with instability and just enough shear to produce a broken line of severe thunderstorms in western MA and northern CT in the late afternoon.  A significant microburst occurred in Erving and Warwick, MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A microburst, with winds estimated at 90 mph began in Erving, MA and moved across Warwick, MA.  In Erving, the damage began along Route 2, which was closed for a time due to downed trees.  Trees, wires, and a power pole were down on Route 2 at East Prospect Street.  Trees and wires were down on a car on Camp Road. Numerous trees were downed on North Shore Road near Laurel Lake.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough of low pressure in western New England combined with instability and just enough shear to produce a broken line of severe thunderstorms in western MA and northern CT in the late afternoon.  A significant microburst occurred in Erving and Warwick, MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Wendell, a tree was down on power lines on Montague Road at Wickett Pond Road. |Relayed by amateur radio.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough of low pressure in western New England combined with instability and just enough shear to produce a broken line of severe thunderstorms in western MA and northern CT in the late afternoon.  A significant microburst occurred in Erving and Warwick, MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS Survey concluded that a microburst, with winds estimated at 90 mph, began in Erving, MA and then moved across Warwick.  In Warwick, trees were down on Quarry Road and people were temporarily stranded at a campground just east of Quarry Road due to fallen trees.  By far, the most extensive damage occurred on Wendell Road east of the campground and on Hockanum Road in the Hockanum Hill section of Warwick.  There were more than a hundred trees downed, mainly pines.  Many were snapped mid-way up and others were uprooted.  Local Fire Department officials indicated that a couple of homes were hit by fallen trees on Wendell Road, one of which suffered damage to the property.  Trees fell in the same direction, from southwest to northeast, indicative of straight-line winds. There were many downed power lines.  Amazingly, no injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough of low pressure in western New England combined with instability and just enough shear to produce a broken line of severe thunderstorms in western MA and northern CT in the late afternoon.  A significant microburst occurred in Erving and Warwick, MA.

A dome of high pressure brought a stretch of hot and humid weather resulting in heat indices reaching between 95F and 104F degrees across western Massachusetts on both August 4 and August 8, 2022.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Amid a hot and humid air mass, scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours across western Massachusetts on August 4, 2022. One storm became severe, downing some trees near Pittsfield. An additional tree was downed from an outflow boundary that moved through.

A dome of high pressure brought a stretch of hot and humid weather resulting in heat indices reaching between 95F and 104F degrees across western Massachusetts on both August 4 and August 8, 2022.

The United States Drought Monitor (USDM) indicated severe drought conditions across much of Berkshire County in Massachusetts starting on August 16, 2022. The previous 30 days had seen less than half of normal rainfall with below normal precipitation persisting since the start of June. A period of hot and dry weather, especially during the first several days of August, contributed to this rapid deterioration of drought conditions. Severe drought in this region continued into the month of September.||The Massachusetts Drought Management Task Force issued a Level 2 (Significant Drought) Declaration for Berkshire County starting on August 24. Residents and businesses were urged to be extremely mindful of their overall water use.||Mandatory water use restrictions were declared in the communities of Cheshire, Williamstown, Adams, Dalton and Hinsdale.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Rehoboth, a CoCoRAHS observer recorded 7.44 inches of rain!  There were a few flooded basements reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front across Rhode Island and southeast Massachusetts provided the focus for heavy rain and scattered thunderstorms.  Four to six inches of rain fell in a portion of southeast Massachusetts, with a max of 7.44 inches in Rehoboth.  An isolated severe thunderstorm occurred in Holyoke in western Massachusetts.

The United States Drought Monitor (USDM) continued to indicate severe drought conditions across much of Berkshire County in Massachusetts through the month of September.||Precipitation the previous 30 days were about 50 to 75 percent of normal but below normal precipitation signals had persisted since the start of June. Above normal temperatures combining with below normal precipitation contributed to the rapid deterioration of drought conditions. Soaking rainfall events during the month of September gradually improved drought conditions across the area with some severe drought persisting into October.||The Massachusetts Drought Management Task Force continued a Level 2 (Significant Drought) Declaration for Berkshire County through September. Residents and businesses were urged to be extremely mindful of their overall water use.||Mandatory water use restrictions continued in the communities of Cheshire, Williamstown, Adams, Dalton and Hinsdale.

The United States Drought Monitor (USDM) continued to indicate severe drought conditions across eastern portions of Berkshire County in Massachusetts into the early part of October before it was downgraded on October 11.||Above normal precipitation from September through October improved drought conditions across the region allowing the severe drought to end.||On October 7, the Massachusetts Drought Management Task Force downgraded Berkshire County back to a Level 0 - Normal Condition status.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds generally were gusting to 50 to 55 mph across Cape Cod during the early morning hours.  In Barnstable, between 725 AM and 735 AM EDT (625 AM and 635 AM EST),  a tree branch and power lines were down in the area of 500 Main Street (Route 6A); a tree was down on wires on Phinneys Lane; a tree was down on Flint Street; a tree was down on wires on Conners Road in the Centerville part of town; and a tree was down on Old Stage Road at Shootflying Hill Road in the Centerville part of town.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front brought 1 to 3 inches of rain to eastern Massachusetts, along with winds that gusted to 40 to 60 mph along the southern and eastern coastline. Some minor street flooding occurred during the morning.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Attleboro, a tree was down on a car on Read Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As low pressure associated with the remnants of Nicole moved along the Appalachians and into western New England, a strong southerly low level jet developed late at night on the 11th across southern New England.  Strong wind gusts occurred overnight in northern Connecticut, Rhode Island, and eastern Massachusetts.  In southeast Massachusetts, a fine line of convection moved through in the early morning of the 12th, which also enhanced wind gusts.  The highest wind gusts reported were in the 40-47 mph range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across southern New England, causing southerly winds that gusted to 40 to 55 mph.  Although leaves were gone from many trees, there was still some scattered tree damage in Massachusetts, northern Connecticut, and northern Rhode Island.  With a strong low level jet aloft, a few of the heavier showers brought down isolated wind gusts estimated near 70 mph in Dunstable, MA.

Strong westerly wind gusts occurred in the wake of a cold front across western Massachusetts on December 1, 2022. Wind gusts peaked between 40 and 50 mph.

A low pressure system brought widespread accumulating snowfall across western Massachusetts on December 11, 2022 before tapering off during the early morning hours on December 12, 2022. Bands of moderate to heavy snow developed during the late afternoon and evening hours bringing a widespread 6 to 10 inches of accumulation to the area.||Key impacts: snow covered roads, travel delays.

A low pressure system brought widespread accumulating snowfall across western Massachusetts on December 11, 2022 before tapering off during the early morning hours on December 12, 2022. Bands of moderate to heavy snow developed during the late afternoon and evening hours bringing a widespread 6 to 10 inches of accumulation to the area.||Key impacts: snow covered roads, travel delays.

A high-impact, long-duration winter storm affected the region from December 15-17, 2022. This was an elevation-dependent storm with heavy snowfall for the higher elevations and a mix of rain and snow in the valleys. Snowfall totals of 10-20 inches were common across areas above 1000 feet with mainly 6 inches or less below.||This was a heavy, wet snow and the weight of the snow caused downed trees and power lines resulting in scattered power outages. A speed restriction went into effect on the Massachusetts Turnpike as a result of the storm.||Key Impacts: Travel Delays, Tree Damage, Power Outages.

A high-impact, long-duration winter storm affected the region from December 15-17, 2022. This was an elevation-dependent storm with heavy snowfall for the higher elevations and a mix of rain and snow in the valleys. Snowfall totals of 10-20 inches were common across areas above 1000 feet with mainly 6 inches or less below.||This was a heavy, wet snow and the weight of the snow caused downed trees and power lines resulting in scattered power outages. A speed restriction went into effect on the Massachusetts Turnpike as a result of the storm.||Key Impacts: Travel Delays, Tree Damage, Power Outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in western Franklin County.  Warning criteria was met as early as 6:30 AM EST on the 16th.  Final totals included:  18.0 inches in Rowe (amateur radio); 16.0 in Hawley (trained spotter); and 11.0 in Ashfield (trained spotter).  In Rowe, at 10 AM EST, the weight of the snow knocked down a tree and wires on Davis Mine Road and at 610 AM EST on the 17th, police reported a tree down on Middletown Hill Road.  In Ashfield at 214 PM EST on the 16th, the Fire Dept. reported a tree down on wires (road unspecified).  In Buckland at 525 AM EST on the 17th, the Fire Dept. reported multiple trees down on wires.  In Conway at 552 AM EST on the 17th, amateur radio operators reported a large tree down on North Poland Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure intensified along the New Jersey coast on the 16th and moved northeast across southeast New England, reaching the Gulf of Maine on the 17th.  The big impact was very heavy elevational snows, with a foot-and-a-half of snow in the east slopes of the Berkshires and 8 to 10 inches in the hills of northern Worcester County.  Elsewhere there was a few inches of rain and gusty winds, both ahead of and behind the system.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in western Hampden County.  Warning criteria was reached as early as 630 AM EST on the 16th.  The final total in Chester was 14.0 inches (amateur radio).  In Granville at 716 AM EST on the 16th, police reported a tree down on wires from the weight of the snow (road unspecified).  In Chester at 759 AM EST on the 16th, the public reported multiple trees down on Round Hill Road (report relayed by amateur radio).   In Blandford at 110 PM EST on the 16th, the public reported power lines down on North Blandford Road (report relayed by amateur radio).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure intensified along the New Jersey coast on the 16th and moved northeast across southeast New England, reaching the Gulf of Maine on the 17th.  The big impact was very heavy elevational snows, with a foot-and-a-half of snow in the east slopes of the Berkshires and 8 to 10 inches in the hills of northern Worcester County.  Elsewhere there was a few inches of rain and gusty winds, both ahead of and behind the system.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow occurred in western Hampshire County.  Warning criteria was reached as early as 6:30 AM on the 16th.  Some final totals included:  Goshen 16.0 inches (amateur radio); Plainfield 13.0 inches (trained spotter); Chesterfield 10.3 inches (trained spotter).  In Chesterfield at 657 AM EST on the 16th, the Fire Dept. reported a tree limb and wires down on a car, from the weight of the snow (report relayed by amateur radio).  In Cummington at 1046 AM EST on the 16th, the public reported a tree down on wires on Wilder Road.  In Worthington at 550 AM EST on the 17th, police reported a large tree down on wires on Witt Hill Road at Guard Road.  In Goshen at 7 AM EST on the 17th, Fire Dept. officials reported a tree down on wires on Ball Road (report relayed by amateur radio).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure intensified along the New Jersey coast on the 16th and moved northeast across southeast New England, reaching the Gulf of Maine on the 17th.  The big impact was very heavy elevational snows, with a foot-and-a-half of snow in the east slopes of the Berkshires and 8 to 10 inches in the hills of northern Worcester County.  Elsewhere there was a few inches of rain and gusty winds, both ahead of and behind the system.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Westwood, a tree was down on Canton Street.  Public report was relayed by amateur radio.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Ashby, an amateur radio operator reported 11 inches of snow and trees down on West Road and Piper Road. This is being listed as Winter Weather, rather than Heavy Snow, because Ashby was the only town in MA Zone 26 that had heavy snow... Townsend had 3.5 inches, Pepperell had 1 inch, and Ayer reported 0.3 inches, so the zone average was below warning criteria.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure intensified along the New Jersey coast on the 16th and moved northeast across southeast New England, reaching the Gulf of Maine on the 17th.  The big impact was very heavy elevational snows, with a foot-and-a-half of snow in the east slopes of the Berkshires and 8 to 10 inches in the hills of northern Worcester County.  Elsewhere there was a few inches of rain and gusty winds, both ahead of and behind the system.

Two separate frontal systems merged to form a powerful winter storm over the Great Lakes from December 22 to December 24 bringing multiple hazards to the region including heavy rain, snow, strong winds and a very cold air mass in its wake.||Widespread rainfall amounts of 0.50 of an inch to 2 inches were observed across the region. Some poor drainage flooding occurred across some locations across the county due to the combination of rain and snow melt.||As colder air returned, a period of snow brought snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches to the region.||Strong pre-frontal and post-frontal winds occurred with this event with a few gusts between 40 and 50 mph. A few trees and power lines were downed across the county which led to scattered power outages. At least 4000 people lost power during this event.||The combination of colder air and continued gusty winds led to wind chill values dipping to 15 to 20 below zero by the early morning hours on December 24.||Key impacts: tree and structural damage, power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Lynn at 230 AM EST, a large tree branch was down on South Common Street.  In Ipswich at 530 AM EST, a tree fell into a house on Edge Street.  No injuries were reported.  In Salem at 634 AM EST, a large tree branch fell onto a house on Dodge Street, damaging a window and a section of fencing.  In Salisbury at 645 AM EST, a mobile mini-storage container was blown over and damaged, off of Bridge Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure deepened rapidly as it tracked through the eastern Great Lakes.|The storm produced damaging southeast to south winds across much of southern New England and minor to moderate coastal flooding the east and south coasts.  There were two rounds of strong wind gusts -- one in the morning and one in the late afternoon and evening.  Two to 3.5 inches of rain fell across much of RI and interior MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Lawrence at 508 PM, the ASOS at KLWM Airport recorded a gust to 59 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure deepened rapidly as it tracked through the eastern Great Lakes.|The storm produced damaging southeast to south winds across much of southern New England and minor to moderate coastal flooding the east and south coasts.  There were two rounds of strong wind gusts -- one in the morning and one in the late afternoon and evening.  Two to 3.5 inches of rain fell across much of RI and interior MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Dartmouth at 555 AM, Smith Neck Road by Padanaram Bridge was closed due to splashover and debris.  In New Bedford at 646 AM, police reported 1 foot of coastal flooding on roadways and at 717 AM, Fort Taber Park was closed due to coastal flooding.  In Freetown at 730 AM, there was flooding on Water Street from the tidal influence of the Assonet River.  In Dartmouth at 738 AM, Cushman Lane at Russells Mills Road was closed due to coastal flooding.  In Westport at 8 AM, amateur radio reported that Westport Harbor had 2 feet of street flooding on harbor roads and water was up to the bottom of DPW vehicles.  In Westport at 1005 AM, rocks were piled up several inches deep on East Beach Road, just to the east of Horseneck Beach, requiring a bulldozer to remove them.

There were two rounds of strong wind gusts -- one in the morning and one in the late afternoon and evening.  Two to 3.5 inches of rain fell across much of RI and interior MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In North Andover at 606 AM, news media showed a tree on a house and a car, significantly damaging the car, on Route 114 (Turnpike Street).  Also in North Andover, at 608 AM, the Fire Department reported a large tree down on high tension wires on Johnson Street.  In Andover at 610 AM, police reported a tree down near the intersection of Juniper Road and Chandler Road.  A CWOP observed wind gust of 57 mph was reported from Bradford, MA at 520 PM.  Nearby, in Lawrence, the ASOS at the Lawrence Airport (KLWM) recorded a gust to 59 mph at 508 PM.  Similar gusts likely occurred during the morning event.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure deepened rapidly as it tracked through the eastern Great Lakes.|The storm produced damaging southeast to south winds across much of southern New England and minor to moderate coastal flooding the east and south coasts. In Stow, amateur radio operators reported a large tree down on Harvard Road at Sylvan Drive.  In Chelmsford at 738 AM, amateur radio relayed a public report of trees and wires down on Acton Road between Fay Street and Parker Road.  In Tewksbury at 803 AM, wires were reported down on a bus on Rogers Street.  In North Billerica at 5 PM, a tree fell, resulting in deck and fence damage of a private property.  In Acton at 640 PM, a 35-foot long by 10-inch diameter tree limb was down on Strawberry Hill Road.  In Stow at 7 PM, amateur radio reported multiple power lines down.  In Concord at 740 PM, the public reported numerous trees and wires down on Strawberry Hill Road.  At 446 PM, a CWOP station in Westford recorded a gust to 56 mph.  At 448 PM, the ASOS at the Beford Airport (KBED) recorded a gust to 52 mph.

Two separate frontal systems merged to form a powerful winter storm over the Great Lakes from December 22 to December 24 bringing multiple hazards to the region including heavy rain, snow, strong winds and a very cold air mass in its wake.||Widespread rainfall amounts of 0.50 of an inch to 2 inches were observed across the region. Some poor drainage flooding occurred across some locations across the county due to the combination of rain and snow melt.||As colder air returned, a period of snow brought snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches to the region.||Strong pre-frontal and post-frontal winds occurred with this event with a few gusts between 40 and 50 mph. A few trees and power lines were downed across the county which led to scattered power outages. At least 4000 people lost power during this event.||The combination of colder air and continued gusty winds led to wind chill values dipping to 15 to 20 below zero by the early morning hours on December 24.||Key impacts: tree and structural damage, power outages.

Two separate frontal systems merged to form a powerful winter storm over the Great Lakes from December 22 to December 24 bringing multiple hazards to the region including heavy rain, snow, strong winds and a very cold air mass in its wake.||Widespread rainfall amounts of 0.50 of an inch to 2 inches were observed across the region. Some poor drainage flooding occurred across some locations across the county due to the combination of rain and snow melt.||As colder air returned, a period of snow brought snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 inches to the region.||Strong pre-frontal and post-frontal winds occurred with this event with a few gusts between 40 and 50 mph. A few trees and power lines were downed across the county which led to scattered power outages. At least 4000 people lost power during this event.||The combination of colder air and continued gusty winds led to wind chill values dipping to 15 to 20 below zero by the early morning hours on December 24.||Key impacts: tree and structural damage, power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ocean effect snow, on west-southwest flow, which is a rarity, accumulated much of Dec. 24 and into the 25th.  Six to nine inches fell by the time it completely ended in the late morning of the 25th.  A trained spotter in Edgartown reported 9 inches, 7.5 of which fell prior to 8 PM on the 24th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind a departing storm, a blast of arctic air on southwest winds produced a rare single band of ocean effect snow that affected Cape Cod and the Islands, and especially Martha���s Vineyard.  Nine inches of ocean-effect snow fell on Martha's Vineyard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system and its associated cold pool aloft led to the development of scattered thunderstorms, one of which caused a lightning injury.

Temperatures soared into the 90s throughout the lower elevations of western Massachusetts on July 19th, reaching as high as the mid-90s. The combination of the heat and a humid airmass brought heat indices into the 95 to 105 degree range. Heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again in some of the lower elevations again on July 20th, but were not quite as high as the previous day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Newburyport, a house on High Street was hit by lightning. There was smoke coming out of the electrical box in the basement.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short-wave trough approached the region aloft while a pre-frontal trough moved into the area at the surface. producing severe thunderstorms in the afternoon. Dewpoints were between 70 and 75, providing ample moisture.  With only marginal shear, the storms were slow-moving and produced torrential downpours, which led to significant flooding, especially in urban areas of northeast Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service survey team concluded that a weak, narrow, but relatively long tornado occurred during the evening on Sunday, August 2 in western Massachusetts. It began in the southeast part of Sandisfield just west of south Main Street in Berkshire County just before crossing into Hampden County at Tolland Road (see StormData for Massachusetts, Central and East) after just 0.25 miles. The tornado continued for a total path length of 7.8 miles with a maximum path width of 100 yards. In Sandisfield, some tree damage was observed on Carpenter Lane and on South Main street at and just north of the Mile 4 marker. A home there had its upper window blown in, shingles ripped off, and the portico was lifted upward, enabling the supporting post to be shifted outward. Some corn stalks were flattened and a neighbor's fence was blown down. The EF-scale rating was EF-0, with estimated maximum wind speeds of 80 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong warm front moving northeast across southern New England and an approaching short wave trough combined to produce a weak tornado in western Massachusetts during the early evening hours of Sunday, August 2nd, 2020. This tornado touched down just southeast of Sandisfield, MA before crossing into Hampden County, resulting in mainly downed trees and minor home damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service survey team concluded that a weak, narrow, but relatively long tornado occurred during the evening on Sunday, August 2 in western Massachusetts. It began in the southeast part of Sandisfield (Berkshire County), moved northeast across northwest Tolland (Hampden County), and lifted in the southern portion of Blandford (Hampden County). Damage was mainly to trees but some minor home damage occurred in Sandisfield. The EF-Scale rating was EF-0, with estimated maximum wind speeds of 80 mph. The tornado was on the ground in a mainly continuous path for a little more than 8 miles, with a maximum width of approximately 100 yards.||The tornado began in Sandisfield, just west of South Main Street.  Some tree damage was observed on Carpenter Lane and on South Main Street at and just north of the Mile 4 marker.  A home there had its upper window blown in, shingles ripped off, and the portico was lifted upward, enabling the supporting post to be shifted outward.  Some corn stalks were flattened and a neighbor's fence was blown down.  ||In Tolland, trees were observed to be blown down in various directions from East Otis Road to the west shore of Twining Pond, where drone footage provided by an amateur radio operator showed a couple of dozen trees blown down in a narrow swath.  Continuing to the northeast, many trees were downed on Belden Road and on a narrow portion of Schoolhouse Road just north of Belden Road.  The damage became sporadic as it ended with some wires downed in Blandford, just west of the north end of the Cobble Mountain Reservoir.  One tree was observed down near the Blandford Highway Department on Otis Stage Road (Route 23).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong warm front moving northeast across southern New England and an approaching short wave trough combined to produce a weak tornado in western Massachusetts during the early evening hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed in the town of Pittsfield, Peru, Hinsdale and northwest of Dalton. Large tree limbs were also downed in the town of Richmond.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias tracked northeast from the eastern Carolinas across the mid-Hudson Valley and into New England. The center of the storm passed close to Albany, NY on August 4th. This storm brought tropical storm force winds and moderate rainfall to western Massachusetts through the period. These winds caused widespread damage with numerous reports of downed trees and wires across Massachusetts. Power outages were also widespread with over 15,000 outages across Berkshire County and over 75,000 state-wide. Every town in the county had some power outages. The town of Sandisfield was particularly hard-hit, with over 70% of the town losing power and 45 reports of trees down on wires. A Sandisfield resident was critically injured when a tree fell on her car.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were 45 reports of trees down on wires in Sandisfield. One tree struck a woman in a vehicle on Town Hill Road, resulting in a broken neck, ribs, and back.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias tracked northeast from the eastern Carolinas across the mid-Hudson Valley and into New England. EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was scattered, but costly damage in northern Worcester County. In Fitchburg at 148 PM EDT, a tree was down on Ashburnham Hill Road and at 514 PM EDT, a tree fell into a house on Highview Street.  In Leicester at 215 PM EDT, a tree fell onto a pickup truck, crushing it.  Wires were down on Mulberry Street.  In Leominster at 644 PM EDT, a tree fell onto a house on Lancaster Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous trees and wires down, along with widespread power outages, especially in the slopes of the Berkshires.  In Huntington, a tree was down on Route 112; a tree was down on County Road; and a tree was down on Goss Hill Road.  In Williamsburg, a tree was down on Briar Hill Road and a tree and wires were down on Nash Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was widespread damage, mainly between 3 PM and 530 PM EDT.  Numerous trees were downed, as well as power lines, causing power outages.  At 420 PM EDT, the ASOS at KBAF in Westfield, MA measured a wind gust to 62 mph (54 kt).  In Westfield, trees fell onto houses on Mills and Court Streets, Myrtle Street, and Atwater Road. Also in Westfield, a tree and wires were down on Northwest Road and a tree was down on Honeypot Road.  In Springfield, a tree fell onto a house at Trafton and Dickinson Streets and a tree fell onto a house and car on Wendell Street.  In Southwick, a tree was down on College Highway and another tree was down on Berkshire Avenue.  Also in Southwick, wires were down on Granville Road.  In Agawam, a tree was down on Parker Street and at the intersection of Silver and Suffield Streets.  In Chicopee, a tree was down on Bardon Street.  In Wilbraham, numerous trees and power lines were down on Stony Hill Road near the elementary school.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous power outages from trees and wires being downed.  In Blandford, wires were down on Beech Hill Road, several trees were down on Blair Road, and a tree was down on Route 23.  In Tolland, a tree and wires were down on River Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Milford, at 355 PM EDT, a trained spotter reported a wind gust to 63 mph.  At 430 PM, the ASOS at the Worcester Airport recorded a gust to 47 mph (41 kt).  In Worcester, a tree was down on Dogwood Road at 425 PM EDT.  Also in Worcester a few minutes later, at 430 PM EDT, a person was injured and transported to a hospital when a tree fell onto a car on West Boylston Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed.  In Rehoboth at 418 PM EDT, a tree fell onto a person on Reservoir Avenue. That person was injured but was conscious and alert at the scene.  In Attleboro at 5 PM EDT, several large oak trees were snapped 25 feet above the ground. In North Attleboro, a tree was snapped in half.  In Mansfield, a small tree was snapped at the base on South Main Street.  In Taunton at 556 PM EDT, trees were down on both Davis Street and Caswell Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Chelmsford at 518 PM EDT, a large tree and power lines were down on Robin Hill Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Arlington, the public reported a tree down on a car at 430 PM EDT.  In Newton Highlands, amateur radio operators reported a tree down blocking the MBTA D Line tracks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Franklin, there were multiple locations with trees and wires down.  In Norwood, large branches and wires were down on Nichols Street near Vernon Street.  In Foxboro, a NWS employee reported a tree down on Independence Drive.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 529 PM EDT, a mesonet site at Hull recorded a wind gust to 60 mph (52 kt).  At 534 PM EDT, a mesonet site at Duxbury recorded a gust to 61 mph (53 kt).  The AWOS site at Marshfield (KGHG) recorded a gust to 63 mph at 555 PM EDT. No reports of wind damage were received in eastern Plymouth County, but we are sure that, like everywhere throughout eastern MA, there was scattered tree and power line damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 530 PM EDT, a mesonet site at Deer Island, just off of Boston, measured a gust to 59 mph (51 kt).  At 534 PM EDT, a mesonet site at Pleasure Bay in Boston recorded a gust to 62 mph (54 kt).  At 540 PM EDT, the ASOS at Logan International Airport recorded a gust to 53 mph (46 kt).  There were no reports of damage in Suffolk County, but it is likely that there were a few tree limbs or trees downed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Isaias moved from coastal Virginia eastern New York state, near the Connecticut/Massachusetts border on Tuesday, August 4.  As the storm reached the New York City area, southerly winds were maximizing across southern New England, causing widespread wind damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass was in place across the region. This resulted in scattered thunderstorms on the afternoon and evening of August 10th. One of these storms became severe and led to a report of downed trees and wires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Townsend, trees, a utility pole, and power lines were down on Spaulding Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave trough moving from Quebec to northern New England led to a convective complex along the border of New Hampshire and Massachusetts in the late morning, which triggered a few severe thunderstorms in northeast Massachusetts.  Later in the day, severe storms were focused mainly on the sea breeze convergence in eastern and southeastern Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Lowell, a section of Raven Road had two feet of street flooding, with the road blocked.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into southern New England caused locally heavy showers, which caused some flooding in northeast Massachusetts during the early evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Beverly, a car was stuck in street flooding on Pleasant Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving into southern New England caused locally heavy showers, which caused some flooding in northeast Massachusetts during the early evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred from about Noon EDT until 3 PM EDT on Cape Cod.  Some peak gusts from mesonet sites included 47 mph at Chapin Beach in Dennis; 45 mph at Hatch Beach in Eastham; 45 mph at Kalmus Beach in Barnstable; and 43 mph at Chatham. The AWOS at the MA Military Reservation/Otis AFB recorded a gust to 43 mph at 255 PM EDT.   The ASOS at Hyannis recorded a gust to 39 mph at 211 PM EDT.  In Hyannis at 140 PM EDT, a tree was down on a driveway on Gray Lane.  In Orleans at 216 PM EDT, a tree was down on Brick Hill Road near Dylan's Way.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Teddy passed well to the east of Massachusetts, as it headed toward the Canadian maritime provinces.  Strong winds gusted to between 40 and 47 mph in eastern Massachusetts. Also, a storm surge of up to 2.5 feet, combined with relatively high astronomical tides, produced mainly minor coastal flooding in eastern and southeastern Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds gusted to between 35 and 40 mph between 1 PM EDT and 245 PM EDT in eastern Plymouth County.  At 134 PM EDT, a mesonet site in Duxbury recorded a gust to 40 mph.  At 131 PM EDT, the ASOS at Plymouth Airport (KPYM) recorded a gust to 36 mph.  In Norwell, at 233 PM EDT,  a tree was blown down on Stetson Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Teddy passed well to the east of Massachusetts, as it headed toward the Canadian maritime provinces.  Strong winds gusted to between 40 and 47 mph in eastern Massachusetts. Also, a storm surge of up to 2.5 feet, combined with relatively high astronomical tides, produced mainly minor coastal flooding in eastern and southeastern Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Boston at 308 PM EDT, two southbound lanes on Morrissey Blvd. between Freeport Street and UMass-Boston were closed due to coastal flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Yarmouth at 324 PM EDT, minor flooding was reported in the parking lot at Grey's Beach and at 615 PM EDT, there was two feet of coastal flooding on Shore Road.  In Chatham at 430 PM EDT, there was minor street flooding in the Little Beach area along Little Beach Road up to Seagull Road and there was flooding on Old Wharf Road and Salt Pond Road at Scatteree Road.  Also in Chatham at 608 PM EDT, there was 3 feet of coastal flooding on Seagull Road just south of Starfish Lane.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Milton, the ASOS at the Blue Hill Observatory (KMQE) recorded a wind gust to 72 mph at 739 AM EDT, after having recording gusts to 70 mph at 648 AM EDT and 60 mph at 5 AM EDT.  In Quincy at 622 AM EDT, a tree was down on a car on Elmwood Avenue at Farrington Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front produced a fine line of low-topped convection that moved across the region from west to east during the morning.  A southerly low level jet of 80 knots at 850 mb, combined with fully leafed trees, helped cause damaging winds.  In addition, heavy rain, totaling 2 to 2.75 inches fell in Franklin and Hampshire Counties in western Massachusetts.

In Taunton at 630 AM EDT, a tree was down on Bay Road at Jackson Street.  In Rehoboth at 711 AM EDT, a tree was down on power lines on Pine Street.  In Raynham at 744 AM EDT, a tree was down on a car on Route 44.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Southwest winds gusted to 40-50 mph ahead of an approaching front.  In Falmouth, a large tree was down on Gifford Street at AmVets Avenue.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line formed in New York State then raced eastward in the late afternoon and early evening, gathering strength as it raced across Massachusetts, northeast Connecticut, and northern Rhode Island. Hundreds of thousands of people were left without power in southern New England, as there was widespread tree and power line damage from winds generally gusting to between 50 and 80 mph.  The Storm Prediction Center officially classified it as a derecho.  Along the line, an isolated brief tornado touched down in Millis, Massachusetts.  Prior to the derecho, strong southwest winds gusted to 40-50 mph in the early afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 52 knots was recorded at the Harriman-and-West Airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high-end severe weather event unfolded across the Northeast on Wednesday October 7, 2020. A line of thunderstorms originated across New York state and moved eastward into New England during the afternoon hours, producing widespread damage. Over a dozen reports occurred across Berkshire County. Both the Harriman-and-West and Pittsfield Municipal airports measured a wind gust of 60 mph as the line moved through. One man was killed when a tree fell onto him on a golf cart at the Wyantenuck Country Club. This event was classified as a serial derecho based on the 320 mile long damage swath and distribution of significant wind gusts (75 mph and above). The fact that trees across the region were fully leafed exacerbated the resulting wind damage and produced widespread power outages. There were over 2,500 power outages across western Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were downed.

Hundreds of thousands of people were left without power in southern New England, as there was widespread tree and power line damage from winds generally gusting to between 50 and 80 mph.  The Storm Prediction Center officially classified it as a derecho.  Along the line, an isolated brief tornado touched down in Millis, Massachusetts.  Prior to the derecho, strong southwest winds gusted to 40-50 mph in the early afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the Leeds section of Northampton, a tree was down on Chesterfield Road.

Prior to the derecho, strong southwest winds gusted to 40-50 mph in the early afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a man on a golf cart at the Wyantenuck Country Club golf course resulting in a fatality. Time was estimated by radar.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high-end severe weather event unfolded across the Northeast on Wednesday October 7, 2020. A line of thunderstorms originated across New York state and moved eastward into New England during the afternoon hours, producing widespread damage. Over a dozen reports occurred across Berkshire County. Both the Harriman-and-West and Pittsfield Municipal airports measured a wind gust of 60 mph as the line moved through. One man was killed when a tree fell onto him on a golf cart at the Wyantenuck Country Club. This event was classified as a serial derecho based on the 320 mile long damage swath and distribution of significant wind gusts (75 mph and above). The fact that trees across the region were fully leafed exacerbated the resulting wind damage and produced widespread power outages. There were over 2,500 power outages across western Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In both Deerfield and Whately, multiple trees were down in Interstate 91, with the highway blocked.

The Storm Prediction Center officially classified it as a derecho.  Along the line, an isolated brief tornado touched down in Millis, Massachusetts.  Prior to the derecho, strong southwest winds gusted to 40-50 mph in the early afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Devens Fire Chief reported five injuries from Fort Devens when a military-grade tent was lifted up and blown down an embankment by thunderstorm winds. It occurred during a training exercise. Five people were taken to the hospital, treated, and released.  Four of the injuries were minor, but one trainee, who was holding onto the tent, was also lifted up and blown 40 feet down the embankment, and received a concussion.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on information received from emergency management officials and based on Doppler radar imagery, the National Weather Service conducted a survey on Oct. 15 and was able to determine that a weak tornado circulation occurred in a small portion of the town of Millis, MA on October 7.  It was embedded within the larger area of derecho/straight-line wind damages that occurred.  It was on the ground for less than a minute, traveled about one-half mile, had a path width of only 50 yards, and estimated maximum wind speeds of 75 to 80 mph.||The tornado began near Orchard Street, just to the west of Ridge Street, and traveled east-southeastward to the Oak Grove Playground/Millis Historical Commission on Exchange Street.  On Orchard Street, the tops of a few large trees were sheared off.  According to one resident, she had two trees down from west to east in her back yard, but she observed the wind change directions and the aforementioned tree tops were blown northward, landing in her yard.  At the Oak Grove Playground, a large tree was downed from west to east but a metal lamp post was blown northwestward toward that tree.  Other trees were observed down from as far west as Tupello Road to as far south as Causeway Street and Island Road.  Damage reportedly went as far east as Environmental Drive, Larch Road, and Dwight Street, but that had since been cleaned up.  Those damage areas likely were associated with the broader straight-line winds of the large-scale derecho that impacted much of Massachusetts, northeast Connecticut, and northern Rhode Island on October 7th.

Hundreds of thousands of people were left without power in southern New England, as there was widespread tree and power line damage from winds generally gusting to between 50 and 80 mph.  The Storm Prediction Center officially classified it as a derecho.  Along the line, an isolated brief tornado touched down in Millis, Massachusetts.  Prior to the derecho, strong southwest winds gusted to 40-50 mph in the early afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Milton, atop the Blue Hill, the ASOS at the Blue Hill Observatory (KMQE) recorded a wind gust to 68 mph.

A cold air mass filtered into the region and interacted with moisture from Tropical Cyclone Zeta. This resulted in a light, early season snowfall event with highest amounts of 3 to 5 inches mainly across the high terrain of the Berkshires.

A cold air mass filtered into the region and interacted with moisture from Tropical Cyclone Zeta. This resulted in a light, early season snowfall event with highest amounts of 3 to 5 inches mainly across the high terrain of the Berkshires.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to 40 to 45 mph in the early morning hours.  In Marshfield at 545 AM EDT, two large trees were down at the intersection of Arlington Street and Washington Avenue.  In Cohasset at 650 AM EDT, a tree was down on Doane Street.  In Plymouth at 735 AM EDT,  a tree was down on a car on Black Cat Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Immediately after winds and rainfall associated with post-tropical cyclone Zeta (which passed well to our southeast) diminished, a new system approached.  This was a rapidly moving upper level low and its associated upper jet max, which moved northeastward from the Mississippi Valley and low pressure again passed to the south of New England. Cold air was streaming into the region from the north. The result was some heavy, wet snow across the region, with many areas receiving 3 to 6 inches. The weight of the snow caused scattered tree and power line damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to between 40 and 45 mph.  In Wareham at 630 AM EDT, a tree was down on Harmony Lane.  In Marion at 635 AM EDT, a tree was down on power lines on Beach Street.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totals ranged from 4.0 to 6.6 inches in southern Worcester County, with an average around 5.5 inches.  A NWS employee in Westborough reported 6.6 inches.  Totals of 6.5 inches were reported from trained spotters and amateur radio operators in Worcester, Milford, and Grafton.  The official measurement at the Worcester Airport was 6.2 inches.  Other reports included 6.1 inches in Auburn, 5.8 inches in Millbury, 5.5 inches in Northborough, and 5.3 inches in Sutton.  In Dudley at 11 AM EDT, a tree was down on West Main Street from the weight of the snow.  In Southborough at 250 PM EDT, a large tree was down on wires on Middle Road from the weight of the snow.  In Worcester at 405 PM EDT, a tree was down on Winifred Avenue from the weight of the snow.

In Easton at 1125 AM EDT, a tree and wires were down on Turnpike Street at the Raynham line due to the weight of the snow. At 11 AM EDT in Brookline (which is technically in Norfolk County but considered part of MA Zone 15), a tree was down on Sumner Road, due to the weight of the snow.  In Boston, between 1110 AM EDT and 1130 AM EDT, trees were down on Jamaicaway at Perkins Street and at Willow Pond Road; a large branch was down on Pond Road; and a tree was down on Harrison Avenue at Kneeland Street.

In Whitman at 357 PM EDT, power lines were down on Bedford Street (Route 18).

A Cooperative Observer in Fitchburg reported 5.6 inches. Other amounts included: 5.3 in both Holden and Sutton; 4.4 in Templeton; 4.0 in West Warren, Winchendon, and Westminster; 3.8 in Ashburnham; 3.0 in Spencer; and 2.9 in Barre. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Westhampton, gusty showers downed a tree and wires on Easthampton Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of heavy showers moved through in the evening hours, accompanied by a modest southerly low-level jet.  Intensifying surface low pressure near the south coast of New England enhanced low level convergence.  These gusty showers knocked down some trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved through southern New England in the evening, followed by strong to damaging wind gusts.  A cold front then moved through late in the evening, accompanied by a fine line of thunderstorms, which also produced some damaging winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds generally were gusting to between 60 and 65 mph.  In Westport at Horseneck Beach at 250 PM EST, a wind gust to 64 mph was reported by an amateur radio operator.  In Fairhaven at West Island at 609 PM EST, a trained spotter recorded a gust to 63 mph.  In Somerset at 514 PM EST, a trained spotter reported a gust to 59 mph.  In New Bedford at 353 PM EST, the ASOS at the New Bedford Airport (KEWB) recorded a gust to 53 mph. In Seekonk at 204 PM EST, a large tree was down on County Street at Olney Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure passed well to the west of southern New England, with strong to damaging southerly winds across our region.  In addition, 2.00 to 3.75 inches of rain fell across most of the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds generally were gusting to between 50 and 55 mph across western Essex County.  At 554 PM EST, the Lawrence Airport (KLWM) ASOS recorded a gust to 45 mph, but farther to the east at the coast in Rockport, an amateur radio operator recorded a gust to 63 mph at 550 PM EST.  In Andover at 217 PM EST, a tree was down on Pleasant Street and at 520 PM EST, a tree and wires were down on Abbott Street at Phillips Street.  In West Newbury at 524 PM EST, a tree was down on Bachelor Street.  In Rowley at 522 PM EST, a tree was down on Stackyard Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure passed well to the west of southern New England, with strong to damaging southerly winds across our region.  In addition, 2.00 to 3.75 inches of rain fell across most of the region.

The ASOS system at Blue Hill (KMQE) recorded a gust to 66 mph at 351 PM EST; 63 mph at 451 PM EST; and 68 mph at 551 PM EST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very little snow fell in the Connecticut River Valley, but more than a foot of snow fell in the higher elevations of eastern Hampden County. In Monson amateur radio relayed a report of 12.5 inches. In Wales, at an elevation of 1,100 feet 11.0 inches was reported. However, in Hampden only 2.2 inches was reported and in Wilbraham only 1.5 inches fell.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying storm system produced strong to damaging winds and heavy rain (2-4 inches) which changed to a period of heavy snow in the higher elevations. The low pressure system crossed between Nantucket and Cape Cod before lifting northeast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in northern Worcester County. Some totals included 12.5 inches in Paxton, 10.0 inches in Rutland, 9.3 inches in Petersham, 8.5 inches in Leicester and Hubbardston, 8.0 inches in Holden, 6.7 inches in Boylston, and 6.0 inches in Spencer.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying storm system produced strong to damaging winds and heavy rain (2-4 inches) which changed to a period of heavy snow in the higher elevations. The low pressure system crossed between Nantucket and Cape Cod before lifting northeast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in southern Worcester County. Some representative totals included 9.6 inches at the Worcester Airport, 7.0 inches in Grafton, 5.1 inches in Auburn, and 5.0 in Northbridge.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying storm system produced strong to damaging winds and heavy rain (2-4 inches) which changed to a period of heavy snow in the higher elevations. The low pressure system crossed between Nantucket and Cape Cod before lifting northeast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a 5.5 inch snowfall report in Pepperell.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying storm system produced strong to damaging winds and heavy rain (2-4 inches) which changed to a period of heavy snow in the higher elevations. The low pressure system crossed between Nantucket and Cape Cod before lifting northeast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in northern Middlesex County with amounts ranging from 3 to 6.8 inches. Lesser amounts fell in the southern part of the county. Some totals included 6.8 inches in Hudson, 5.0 inches in Hopkinton, 4.7 inches in Littleton, and 4.5 inches in Sudbury.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying storm system produced strong to damaging winds and heavy rain (2-4 inches) which changed to a period of heavy snow in the higher elevations. The low pressure system crossed between Nantucket and Cape Cod before lifting northeast.

An area of low pressure tracked northward off the East Coast toward New York City on Wednesday, December 16, then eastward to just off Cape Cod on Thursday, December 17. As a result, cold enough air north of this low led to moderate to heavy snowfall across all of eastern New York and western New England. Snow started across the mid-Hudson Valley and northwestern Connecticut during the late afternoon hours on Wednesday, December 16 and then pushed farther north into western Massachusetts during the evening and overnight hours. Snow reached its peak intensity during the overnight hours before gradually winding down during the morning hours on Thursday, December 17.||Bands of heavy snow occurred with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour reported at times. Total snowfall across western Massachusetts generally ranged between 12 to 24 inches with the higher amounts across the northern Berkshires.||Most area school districts across Berkshire County along with businesses and services were closed on Thursday, December 17. More than 11,000 power outages occurred in Pittsfield, Lee, Dalton and Laneborough, most of which were short-lived.||Key impacts: transportation delays, traffic accidents, power outages, school closures.

An area of low pressure tracked northward off the East Coast toward New York City on Wednesday, December 16, then eastward to just off Cape Cod on Thursday, December 17. As a result, cold enough air north of this low led to moderate to heavy snowfall across all of eastern New York and western New England. Snow started across the mid-Hudson Valley and northwestern Connecticut during the late afternoon hours on Wednesday, December 16 and then pushed farther north into western Massachusetts during the evening and overnight hours. Snow reached its peak intensity during the overnight hours before gradually winding down during the morning hours on Thursday, December 17.||Bands of heavy snow occurred with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour reported at times. Total snowfall across western Massachusetts generally ranged between 12 to 24 inches with the higher amounts across the northern Berkshires.||Most area school districts across Berkshire County along with businesses and services were closed on Thursday, December 17. More than 11,000 power outages occurred in Pittsfield, Lee, Dalton and Laneborough, most of which were short-lived.||Key impacts: transportation delays, traffic accidents, power outages, school closures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow ranged from 10 to 20 inches in western Franklin County, in the east slopes of the Berkshires.  Some specific amounts included 20.0 in East Hawley (Co-Op observer), 17.7 inches in Rowe (Co-Op observer), 17.5 inches in Colrain (CoCoRaHS), 17.2 inches in Buckland (CoCoRaHS), 16.3 inches in Conway (CoCoRaHS), 12.5 inches in Leyden (public), and 10.0 inches in Heath (amateur radio).  Winds generally were gusting to 20 to 30 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system produced heavy snow, strong to damaging winds, and minor coastal flooding in southern New England.  This was a tough storm to forecast.  Although it was not deep low pressure and although it passed just south of the 40N/70W benchmark, its precipitation shield was expansive because of a broad 700 mb low over southeast New England, abundant moisture, and a very cold air mass in place.  By far, the heaviest snow fell to the north (Laconia, NH) and west (Binghamton, NY), where more than 3 feet fell.  But amounts ranged from 10 to 20 inches across much of southern New England.  There was some minor coastal flooding at the time of high tide and also a flash freeze in eastern Massachusetts as the storm pulled away to the northeast.

Other reports included 6.2 inches in Fairhaven (amateur radio), 5.8 inches in Acushnet (amateur radio), and 5.0 inches in New Bedford (amateur radio). EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system produced heavy snow, strong to damaging winds, and minor coastal flooding in southern New England.  This was a tough storm to forecast.  Although it was not deep low pressure and although it passed just south of the 40N/70W benchmark, its precipitation shield was expansive because of a broad 700 mb low over southeast New England, abundant moisture, and a very cold air mass in place.  By far, the heaviest snow fell to the north (Laconia, NH) and west (Binghamton, NY), where more than 3 feet fell.  But amounts ranged from 10 to 20 inches across much of southern New England.  There was some minor coastal flooding at the time of high tide and also a flash freeze in eastern Massachusetts as the storm pulled away to the northeast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow generally ranged from 8 to 14 inches across western Plymouth County, with the highest amounts closest to eastern Norfolk County.  Some specific snowfall amounts included 14.2 inches in Whitman (trained spotter), 13.6 inches in Rockland (trained spotter), 11.2 inches in Pembroke (CoCoRaHS), 9.0 inches in East Bridgewater (amateur radio), 8.5 inches in Hanover (amateur radio), 8.0 inches in Lakeville (amateur radio), and 8.0 inches in Middleboro (Twitter report).  Winds generally were gusting to 35 to 40 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow generally ranged 7 to 10 inches in northern Bristol County. Winds generally were gusting to 30 to 40 mph.  Some specific snowfall totals included 10.3 inches at the National Weather Service Forecast Office in Norton, 10.0 inches in Mansfield, 9.4 inches in Dighton, and 7.4 inches in Rehoboth.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 2 to 4 inches on the outer Cape to up to 6 to 7.7 inches on the upper Cape.  More specifically, some snow totals included 7.7 inches in East Sandwich (CoOp Observer), 6.5 inches in West Falmouth (amateur radio), 5.6 inches in Yarmouth (CoCORaHS), 5.5 inches in Hyannis (WOCN radio), 5.0 inches in Harwich (amateur radio), 4.0 inches in Orleans (CoCoRaHS), and 2.7 inches in Eastham (CoCoRaHS).  Peak wind gusts during the afternoon of the 17th included 49 mph at Dennis (CWOP), 46 mph at Hyannis Airport (KHYA ASOS), and 36 mph at the Chatham Airport (KCQX ASOS).

In Scituate at 1226 PM EST, the media posted a video of minor coastal flooding.  In Plymouth at 1244 PM EST, Warren Avenue was closed from coastal flooding.  In Marshfield at 1257 PM EST, minor coastal flooding made Plymouth Avenue impassable and Ocean Street closed near the Esplanade.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed on Route 295 in the Town of Richmond.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracking from the Great Lakes to Hudson Bay advected in an unseasonably warm air mass into the region from Thursday, December 24 to Friday, December 25, 2020. Rain gradually overspread the region from west to east during the day on December 24 with the steadiest, heaviest rainfall during the overnight hours and early morning hours of December 25. Rain showers continued through the day on December 25 and changed to snow showers during the evening and overnight hours of December 25-26 as colder air returned.||The region still dealt with nearly the entire snowpack from the blockbuster winter storm from December 16-17. While the snow compacted over time, very little water was lost from the snow. Observations concluded that between 1.50 to 2.50 inches of water was in the snowpack prior to this event and most if not all of this snow melted.||Rainfall totals across western Massachusetts ranged from 1.00 to 2.50 inches. These amounts do not include the additional 1.50 to 2.50 inches of water that melted from the snowpack. The combination of warm air, rainfall and melting snowpack likely led to a debris flow outside the west portal of the Hoosac Tunnel near North Adams. Eight inches of mud and stone had to be cleared from the rails, resulting in two freight trains being delayed.||In addition to the rainfall, gusty winds accompanied the event with wind gusts reaching 40 to 55 mph. Wind gusts of 48 and 47 mph were recorded at the Harriman-and-West and Pittsfield Municipal airports, respectively. In addition, a tree was downed in the Town of Richmond.||Key Impacts: transportation delays, tree damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 48 mph wind gust was reported at Harriman-and-West Airport in North Adams. A 47 mph wind gust was reported at Pittsfield Municipal Airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds generally were gusting to 55 to 65 mph.  In Duxbury at 7 AM EST, a mesonet station in Duxbury recorded a wind gust to 65 mph and then at 1020 AM EST it reached 68 mph.  In Hull at 617 AM EST, a mesonet site recorded a gust to 63 mph.  Earlier, in Plymouth at 105 AM EST, a tree was down on Black Cat Road.  In Hingham at 849 AM EST, a tree was down on Sherwood Road.  In Cohasset at 9 AM EST, a tree was down on Route 3A.  In Marshfield at 910 AM EST, a 4-foot diameter tree was down on Corn Hill Road.  In Plymouth at 910 AM EST a large tree was down on wires on Ship Pond Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously deep, full-latitude mid-level trough over the Mississippi Valley caused a strong frontal system to move up the Appalachians. It brought strong to damaging winds, heavy rain with minor flooding, and well above normal temperatures to southern New England early on Christmas Day.  Winds generally gusted to 40 to 60 mph, except 65 to 70 mph along the southeast Massachusetts coast.  South winds were blowing more than 100 mph only 2000 feet above the ground in eastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island, but despite temperatures in the lower 60s there, a surface inversion was strong enough to prevent these very damaging winds from reaching the surface.  Two to four inches of rain fell across the region, with the highest totals from central Rhode Island northwestward across northern Connecticut and portions of western and central Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A routine inspection during the morning of Saturday, December 26th resulted in the discovery of a landslide outside the west portal of the Hoosac Tunnel near North Adams. Eight inches of mud and stone had to be cleared from the rails, resulting in two freight trains being delayed. The cause was likely due to the heavy rains on Friday, December 25th.

Accumulating snow occurred in conjunction with an approaching low pressure system. The snow began during the afternoon hours on the 18th before ending during the wee hours of the 19th. Accumulation generally ranged from 2-5 inches. The snow resulted in slippery travel conditions.

Accumulating snow occurred in conjunction with an approaching low pressure system. The snow began during the afternoon hours on the 18th before ending during the wee hours of the 19th. Accumulation generally ranged from 2-5 inches. The snow resulted in slippery travel conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Final snow totals generally ranged from 4-6 inches in northern Worcester County. A ham radio operator reported 6.6 inches in Royalston. Several CO-OP observers in Ashburnham, Winchendon, Hubbardston, Fitchburg, and Lunenburg all reported 5.5 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust Pacific shortwave moved east from the Great Lakes with attendant|primary low tracking well to the north on the 18th bringing accumulating snow Saturday afternoon and night. A secondary low developed in the Gulf of Maine late Sat night which was too far north to stop low level warming from advancing northward across southern New England Saturday night which changed snow to rain/wintry mix before ending. The precipitation ended by early Sunday as the storm moved away, followed by drier and colder weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Final snow totals ranged from 4 to 6 inches. Trained spotters reported 5.6 inches in Pepperell and 5.1 inches in Ayer.

The precipitation ended by early Sunday as the storm moved away, followed by drier and colder weather.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A robust Pacific shortwave moved east from the Great Lakes with attendant|primary low tracking well to the north on the 18th bringing accumulating snow Saturday afternoon and night. A secondary low developed in the Gulf of Maine late Sat night which was too far north to stop low level warming from advancing northward across southern New England Saturday night which changed snow to rain/wintry mix before ending. The precipitation ended by early Sunday as the storm moved away, followed by drier and colder weather.

Multiple rounds of wintry precipitation impacted western Massachusetts on the 6th and 7th. The first was a round of light snow after midnight on 6th to around sunrise, which resulted in up to an inch of snow. Then, periods of freezing rain occurred from the afternoon of the 6th into the morning of the 7th, mainly over the higher terrain. Reports of up to a quarter of an inch of ice accretion were received. The freezing rain quickly turned to a brief period of snow during the afternoon of the 7th as a strong low pressure system passed south of the area. This round of snow resulted in another one to three inches of accumulation. In the wake of the snowfall, westerly winds gusted to 40-55 miles per hour in the afternoon and evening of the 7th. The weight of the heavy snow and ice on trees along with strong winds resulted in a few reports of downed trees. Speed restrictions due to slippery roads were put into effect on the Massachusetts Turnpike.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very strong wind gusts occurred in the mid afternoon hours.  At 403 PM EST, a mesonet site at West Island in Fairhaven recorded a gust to 73 mph.  At 342 PM EST another location in Fairhaven recorded a 65 mph gust.  At 320 PM EST, the ASOS at New Bedford Airport (KBED) recorded a gust to 62 mph.||At 1209 PM EST in Fall River, a utility pole and container was blown into a building on Water Street near the USS-Massachusetts ship.  At 128 PM EST, multiple trees were reported down across Dartmouth.  At 405 PM EST in Fairhaven, a tree was down at Mayflower and Green Streets.  At 445 PM EST in Acushnet, an 18-inch diameter tree was down on a house on Main Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Powerful low pressure moved from eastern Pennsylvania across central Connecticut and central Massachusetts on February 7, 2020.  A southerly jet of 85 to 95 mph was just above the surface at 925 mb.  Damaging winds occurred across much of eastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island with some damage reported farther to the west. There were widespread power outages and numerous trees down, some falling on homes and vehicles.  Late in the evening, as of 11 PM, more than 66,000 residents remained without power.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on surrounding data, winds were estimated to have gusted to 65 mph in southern Plymouth County during the early and mid afternoon hours.  In Mattapoisett at 1228 PM EST, a tree was down on a house on Tinkham Lane and at 353 PM EST a tree was down on a house on Lebron Way.  In Marion at 1228 PM EST, a tree was down on wires on Point Road at Piney Point Road and at 203 PM EST, a tree was down on power lines on Wareham Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1244 PM EST in Raynham, a tree was down on a house at River Brook Road.  At 404 PM EST in North Attleboro, a large tree limb was blown through the roof of a home and multiple large limbs were down blocking Hawthorne Street.  At 231 PM EST, a wind gust to 55 mph was reported at a Taunton CWOP site. At 519 PM EST in Raynham, a large tree was down on a house on Easy Street.  In Mansfield (time unknown), two people were taken to hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries when a tree and wires fell onto a car on West Street.  The live wires delayed access to the patients, per Mansfield Fire Dept. officials.
