EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very damaging wind gusts roared across Cape Cod in the early to mid afternoon hours. A CWOP site at Truro recorded an 80 mph gust at 350 PM. A mesonet site at Chapin Beach on Cape Cod Bay recorded a gust to 77 mph at 337 PM.  The AWOS station at Provincetown Airport (KPVC) recorded a 75 mph gust at 356 PM and a mesonet site in Eastham had a gust to 75 mph at 422 PM.  The were dozens more reports in the 55 to 74 mph range throughout Barnstable County.||Damage was reported at many locations.  In Eastham, trees and wires were down on Great Pond Road.  In Falmouth, a tree was down on English Street and another tree was blocking Davisville Road.  A large tree crushed someone's truck bed.  In Barnstable, power lines were down at Barnstable Road and Winter Street.  In Mashpee, several trees were reported down across the town.  In Dennis, a rubber roof was blown off a building on Old Wharf Road between Beaten Road and Uncle Rolf Road and a large tree was down on wires at Mayfair Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Fitchburg, at 1250 PM EST, a tree was reported down on Elm Street. It also took down power line poles.  At 310 PM EST, a wind gust to 47 mph was recorded at the Worcester Airport ASOS.  Higher gusts were observed in southern Worcester County...at 343 PM EST, a wind gust to 56 mph was observed at a CWOP site in Mendon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous sites in eastern Plymouth County measured gusts between 60 and 62 mph.  Gusts to 62 mph were reported at Duxbury at 325 PM EST, at Hull at 401 PM EST, and at Plymouth at 410 PM EST.  A gust to 61 mph was reported by a mesonet site at Ned's Point at 407 PM EST.  The Plymouth Airport ASOS (KPYM) recorded a gust to 60 mph as early as 111 PM EST.  The Marshfield Airport AWOS (KGHG) recorded a 56 mph gust at 315 PM EST.  In Plymouth...at 350 PM EST a tree was down on wires on Old Sandwich Road; at 4 PM EST a tree was down on wires on Brush Hill Road. In Duxbury at 431 PM EST, a large tree branch smashed a car windshield at the North Hill Country Club on Merry Avenue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Norwell at 132 PM EST, a large tree was down on wires on Pine Street.  In Middleboro at 144 PM EST a tree was down on Thomas Street and at 545 PM EST a large tree was down on Becca Lane.  In Abington (time unknown), a tree fell, blocking Route 18 for a time. Based on stronger winds at the coast but somewhat less inland, we have estimated gusts at approximately 58 mph.

At 353 PM EST, a gust to 59 mph was reported by ham radio in Quincy.  CBS Boston reported that a tree fell on multiple cars in Braintree (time unknown), fortunately without injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 338 PM EST, a CWOP station in Wrentham measured a gust to 63 mph.  At 346 PM EST, the Norwood Airport ASOS (KOWD) recorded a gust to 55 mph.  In Norwood at 4 PM EST, a 12 inch diameter healthy oak tree limb was snapped off from the top.  In Wrentham at 620 PM EST, a tree was down in Hayden Woods.  In Wellesley (time unknown), a large tree fell, closing Route 135 for a time.  CBS Boston reported that in Dedham (time unknown), a large tree smashed a parked car.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Powerful low pressure moved from eastern Pennsylvania across central Connecticut and central Massachusetts on February 7, 2020.  A southerly jet of 85 to 95 mph was just above the surface at 925 mb.  Damaging winds occurred across much of eastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island with some damage reported farther to the west. There were widespread power outages and numerous trees down, some falling on homes and vehicles.  Late in the evening, as of 11 PM, more than 66,000 residents remained without power.

Boston's Logan International Airport ASOS (KBOS) recorded a gust to 56 mph at 257 PM EST.  In Boston at approximately 4 PM EST scaffolding fell from a building on Causeway Street near TD Garden, hitting one person and sending them to the hospital with minor injuries. Also in Boston at 459 PM EST, a tree was down on wires on Station Street.

A period of accumulating snow occurred from around midnight to noon on the 10th. Accumulation generally ranged from three to nine inches over the northern Berkshires, mainly over the high terrain. The snow resulted in speed and tractor trailer restrictions on the Mass Pike between the New York border and Exit 3.

A period of accumulating snow occurred from around midnight to noon on the 10th. Accumulation generally ranged from three to nine inches over the northern Berkshires, mainly over the high terrain. The snow resulted in speed and tractor trailer restrictions on the Mass Pike between the New York border and Exit 3.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall was very elevation-dependent.  A Cooperative Observer in East Hawley reported 7.2 inches of snow.  Other reports included 7.0 inches in Heath and Rowe and 8.0 inches in Leyden.  Lesser amounts occurred in other parts of western Franklin County with only 4.0 inches in Shelburne and Greenfield.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell during the morning of February 10 in the higher elevations of the east slopes of the Berkshires.  It was caused by a warm front that extended southeastward from a clipper type of low pressure system moving through the Great Lakes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 5.5 inches in Williamsburg to 7.1 inches in Plainfield.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 855 AM EST, a wind gust to 61 mph was measured at Woods Hole in Falmouth.  At 1002 AM EST, a mesonet site at Chapin Beach in Dennis recorded a gust to 59 mph.|In Falmouth at 2 PM EST, a tree was downed on Ashumet Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure in New York state moved north into eastern Canada.  It was followed by a cold front that moved east across southern New England. The post-frontal tight pressure gradient caused strong southwest to west winds that gusted to 40 to 60 mph and  caused some damage across Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusting to 50 to 55 mph caused numerous trees to fall.  In Tyngsboro at 11 AM EST, a large branch was down on Lakeview Street.  In Billerica at 1210 PM EST, a tree was down on Treble Cove Road.  In Tewksbury at 1230 PM EST, a tree and wires were down on Lake Street.  In Lincoln at 148 PM EST, a tree and wires were down on Baker Bridge Road.  In Concord at 335 PM EST, a tree was down on Old Marlboro Road.  In Bedford at 415 PM EST, a tree was down on wires on Wildwood Drive.  In Hopkinton at 422 PM EST, trees were down on Spring Street.  In Chelmsford at 543 PM EST, a tree and wires were down on Cortland Drive.  At 1117 AM EST, the Bedford Airport ASOS (KBED) recorded a gust to 47 mph.  But a 56 mph gust was measured at the Lawrence  (KLWM) ASOS, so we estimate that the average was 50 to 55 mph gusts.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure in New York state moved north into eastern Canada.  It was followed by a cold front that moved east across southern New England. The post-frontal tight pressure gradient caused strong southwest to west winds that gusted to 40 to 60 mph and  caused some damage across Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to between 60 and 66 mph during the overnight hours.  At 822 PM EST on March 6, the ASOS at Nantucket Airport (KACK) gusted to 60 mph; at 138 AM EST on March 7, it recorded a gust to 62 mph; and 60 mph at 427 AM EST.  An amateur radio station recorded a peak gust to 66 mph at 128 AM on March 7 in the Pocomo section of Nantucket.  A CWOP site at Siasconset recorded a gust to 59 mph at 831 PM EST on the 6th and to 63 mph at 1145 PM EST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bomb cyclone was located over the ocean waters well to the southeast of Nantucket.  It caused some light snow over southeast Massachusetts, but more importantly, winds gusted to more than 60 mph, causing some damage.

A late season snowfall impacted western Massachusetts on Monday, March 23rd, 2020. This was brought on by an anomalously cold air mass interacting with a coastal low pressure system. Snowfall totals ranged from one inch in southeast Berkshire County up to almost nine inches in northeast Berkshire County.

A late season snowfall impacted western Massachusetts on Monday, March 23rd, 2020. This was brought on by an anomalously cold air mass interacting with a coastal low pressure system. Snowfall totals ranged from one inch in southeast Berkshire County up to almost nine inches in northeast Berkshire County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Co-Operative Observer in East Hawley reported 9.8 inches of snow.  Other reports included 8.0 inches in Colrain, 7.4 inches in Heath, and 7.0 inches in Rowe.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from south of Long Island to south of Nantucket late on March 23rd and then to Nova Scotia on the morning of March 24th. Snow changed to rain in eastern Massachusetts, but a band of heavy snow set up in the higher elevation areas in the east slopes of the Berkshires and in the northern Worcester Hills.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a Public report of 7.8 inches of snow in West Townsend.  A Trained Spotter in Pepperell reported 7.2 inches of snow.  And in Ashby, there was a Public report of 6.5 inches of snow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from south of Long Island to south of Nantucket late on March 23rd and then to Nova Scotia on the morning of March 24th. Snow changed to rain in eastern Massachusetts, but a band of heavy snow set up in the higher elevation areas in the east slopes of the Berkshires and in the northern Worcester Hills.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow totals ranged from 5.5 inches to 8.0 inches.  The highest was a public report in Royalston of 8.0 inches.  Other reports included an amateur radio observer in Winchendon with 7.5 inches; a Public report of 7.2 inches in Fitchburg; a Trained Spotter report of 6.4 inches in Lunenburg; a Trained Spotter report of 5.8 inches in Boylston; an amateur radio report of 5.5 inches in Ashburnham; and a Public report of 5.5 inches in Sterling.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from south of Long Island to south of Nantucket late on March 23rd and then to Nova Scotia on the morning of March 24th. Snow changed to rain in eastern Massachusetts, but a band of heavy snow set up in the higher elevation areas in the east slopes of the Berkshires and in the northern Worcester Hills.
A warm front brought showers and a few rumbles of thunder to western Massachusetts on Sunday, March 29th. There was one report of 1 inch hail in Berkshire county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large hail, ranging from quarter to half-dollar size, occurred for three minutes in southern Leicester, near the Spencer line.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Elevated instability combined with an upper level short wave trough to produce scattered severe thunderstorms during the mid evening hours across portions of mainly central and eastern Massachusetts. Large hail, ranging from quarter to golf ball size, was reported with a few of these storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 607 AM EST (707 AM EDT), portions of Beach Road were closed to Five Corners in Vineyard Haven.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and intense ocean storm east of New England caused a period of coastal flooding at the time of high tide in the early to mid morning and strong, locally damaging winds from the late morning to mid afternoon.  Heavy rain also fell, with 1.50 to 2.75 inches of rain reported in eastern Massachusetts.  The storm then moved south and passed north of Bermuda on March 4.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1153 PM EST (1253 PM EDT) in Boston, high astronomical tides caused two southbound lanes of Morrissey Blvd., between UMass-Boston and Freeport Street to be closed due to minor coastal flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High astronomical tides produced some very minor coastal flooding around the time of high tide on east coast of MA in the early afternoon.  A strong cold front joined forces with a negatively tilting upper level disturbance to produce a narrow line of severe thunderstorms that impacted south coastal RI and MA late in the afternoon. Strong to damaging winds occurred in southeast MA prior to the arrival of the front, as temperatures rose into the 50s and made for better mixing. Additionally, strong to locally damaging post-frontal winds occurred for a few hours into the evening across central and eastern MA.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Salisbury at 1235 PM EST (135 PM EDT), high astronomical tides caused the temporary closure of Beach Road at the Salisbury Beach State Reservation due to minor coastal flooding.

At 212 PM EST in Westport, a gust to 59 mph was measured.  In nearby Wareham at 237 PM EST, a wind gust to 62 mph also was recorded.  In Dartmouth at 211 PM EST, a tree was down on power lines on Slocum Road.  In Westport at 234 PM EST, a tree was down at the intersection of Division and Horseneck Roads and a large branch was down on Division Road.  In Fairhaven at 250 PM EST, a utility pole was down on Yankee Lane and Mill Road.

A strong storm system impacted the region throughout the day on Monday, April 13th, 2020. This resulted in  thunderstorms and strong to damaging winds across western New England, with several reports of trees and power lines downed.

A strong storm system impacted the region throughout the day on Monday, April 13th, 2020. This resulted in  thunderstorms and strong to damaging winds across western New England, with several reports of trees and power lines downed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Holyoke at 915 AM EST (1015 AM EDT) amateur radio reported a tree down on a car on Columbia Street. In West Springfield at 934 AM EST there was a large tree down on wires in Mittineague Park and at 1114 AM EST there was a large tree down on a house and car on Piper Rd. In Southwick at 1052 AM EST there was a tree down on Klaus Anderson Rd and at 1122 AM EST there was a tree and wires down on George Loomis Rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low pressure system tracked across the Great Lakes and brought strong and damaging winds to all of Massachusetts Monday late morning through the evening.  A very strong and highly anomalous low level jet brought southerly wind gusts of 60-70 mph ahead of a cold front that moved through Monday evening.

In Wilmington at 1127 AM EST there was a tree down on a house on Shawsheen Avenue with 1 injury according to a report from amateur radio. In Wayland there was a large section of a fence blown down on Nob Hill Rd at 1242 PM EST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Fairhaven at 3 PM EST (4 PM EDT) a mesonet station reported a sustained wind of 43 mph. Later at 330 PM EST it reported sustained winds of 44 mph, and at 421 PM EST it reported a wind gust of 62 mph. In Fall River at 506 PM EST a wind gust of 64 mph was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low pressure system tracked across the Great Lakes and brought strong and damaging winds to all of Massachusetts Monday late morning through the evening.  A very strong and highly anomalous low level jet brought southerly wind gusts of 60-70 mph ahead of a cold front that moved through Monday evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Duxbury at 505 PM EST (605 PM EDT) a WeatherFlow station reported a wind gust of 78 mph. In Hull at 326 PM EST a WeatherFlow station reported a wind gust of 69 mph. At the Marshfield Airport a wind gust of 64 mph was reported at 415 PM EST. At Duxbury Bay a WeatherFlow station reported a wind gust of 58 mph at 503 PM EST. In Scituate amateur radio reported a large branch down on Common Street at 10 AM EST and a tree and wires down on Cedarwood Road at 1007 AM EST. In Kingston at 106 PM EST there was a tree down across Main St.

A low pressure system brought light to moderate snowfall to the region late Friday, April 17th into the morning hours of Saturday, April 18th, 2020. This resulted in snowfall totals of 1 to 4 inches across western Massachusetts.

A low pressure system brought light to moderate snowfall to the region late Friday, April 17th into the morning hours of Saturday, April 18th, 2020. This resulted in snowfall totals of 1 to 4 inches across western Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of heavy wet snow clung to trees and power lines.  The highest amount reported was 4.3 inches in Monson, where a tree was reported down at 522 AM EST (622 AM EDT) on Stafford Road (Route 32) near the CT state line.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked just south of southern New England on the 18th. It brought rain that changed over to a wet snow overnight on the 17th into the 18th that clung to newly-leaved trees.  Only 3 to locally 6 inches of snow fell, highest in the higher elevations of northeast CT, northwest RI, and interior MA. However, it was enough to cause some tree damage across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inches of heavy, wet snow clung to trees and power lines, causing significant damage.  The highest total was 5.4 inches in Grafton.  In Milford at 410 AM EST (510 AM EDT), a tree was down on wires at East Main Street at Zain Circle.  In Shrewsbury at 530 AM EST, a tree was down blocking Main Street.  In Charlton at 546 AM EST, a large tree was down on wires on Flint Road and at 9 AM EST a tree and wires were down on Stafford Street.  In Sturbridge at 704 AM EST, wires were down on Fiske Hill Road at Main Street and at 850 AM EST, a large tree was down on Oaks Cove Road near Wells Park Road.  In Uxbridge at 734 AM EST, a large branch was down on wires on High Street.  In Dudley at 805 AM EST, a tree and wires were down on Causeway Shores Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Citizens Weather Observer Program site in Fairhaven, MA measured a sustained wind of 43 mph at 5 PM EST (6 PM EDT).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across southern New England during the afternoon hours.  Strong winds occurred ahead of the front over southeastern Massachusetts, with gusts from 40-57 mph.  There was one report that met criteria for high wind.  No damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted to 45 to 53 mph across the area.  At 943 AM EST (1043 AM EDT), a CWOP station in Mendon recorded a gust to 53 mph.  At 1211 PM EST, the ASOS at Worcester Airport (KORH) gusted to 47 mph.  In Webster at 935 AM EST,  a tree was down on wires on Wawela Road.  In Sturbridge at 935 AM EST, a tree was down on West Sturbridge Road and at 1004 AM EST, a car was hit by a falling tree on Camp Road.  No injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west to northwest winds in the lower atmosphere mixed down to the surface beneath an unusually cold pool aloft...temperatures at 500 mb were -38C.  Winds gusted to 40 to 50 mph from late morning to mid afternoon, causing scattered damage in central and eastern Massachusetts.

In Tewksbury at 1132 AM EST, a tree was down on Pond Street near the Billerica line.  In Marlborough at 1213 PM EST, a large tree was down on Farm Road.  In Chelmsford at 1243 PM EST, a tree was down on a car, just off of Old Westford Road - no injuries reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure meandered off the coast of Nantucket late on the 26th and through the 27th providing a murky, cold, blustery day.  Strong winds from aloft mixed down from around 850 mb over eastern Massachusetts during the overnight and early morning hours, causing some minor wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in East Longmeadow.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level low pressure system passed across northern and central New England, with very cold air aloft (-30C at 500 mb).  This triggered enough instability to produce isolated thunderstorms, one of which became severe, producing large hail in Hampden County of western Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 51 miles per hour was recorded at the Harriman and West Airport in North Adams.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Friday, May 15, 2020, an intense line of thunderstorms quickly developed near Lake Ontario and raced eastward across eastern New York, reaching western Massachusetts by around 7:00 pm. The storms produced several reports of wind damage which were most concentrated in the Pittsfield and Great Barrington areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed, including one into a moving vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Friday, May 15, 2020, an intense line of thunderstorms quickly developed near Lake Ontario and raced eastward across eastern New York, reaching western Massachusetts by around 7:00 pm. The storms produced several reports of wind damage which were most concentrated in the Pittsfield and Great Barrington areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees down in Northfield, closing a portion of Route 10.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a warm, somewhat humid air mass in place, a strong cold front moved through southern New England during the evening hours.  In addition, southern New England was on the southern edge of a strong jet stream aloft. The result was a quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) that moved through Massachusetts.  It caused significant damage in places, tearing the roof of buildings in Holyoke and hundreds of trees downed in parts of north-central and northeast Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damaging winds peeled two roofs off of neighboring apartment buildings in Holyoke's Flats neighborhood, at the intersection of West Street and East Dwight Street.  A total of 140 residents ended up being displaced/homeless (47 families). Bricks from one of the buildings crashed onto West Street, damaging several cars.  Some wooden support beams also rained onto the streets below. Amazingly, no injuries were reported.  Damage figures approximate only.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A microburst with estimated winds of 90-100 mph produced significant damage to trees and homes in a small part of Pepperell.  Several large trees were uprooted near Brookline Street and Cheyenne Road, some onto houses.  Trees were snapped about two to three feet from their bases farther down on Cheyenne Road near Algonquin Road.  A couple of trees were also downed on Gosselin Drive and Seminole Drive.  According to the Emergency Management Director, four telephone poles were snapped and seven homes had damage, six of which were significant with roofs penetrated and garages destroyed by falling trees.  Miraculously, there were no injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Another microburst, with discontinuous damage approximately 1.5 miles in length, occurred in Groton and Westford, from the same storm that produced a microburst in Pepperell.  A drone video showed extensive tree damage near Cow Pond Brook Conservation area in Groton,, with the vast majority of the trees blown down in a straight line.  A wind gust to 89 mph was measured at MIT's Millstone facility near the Groton/Westford line and the public reported a wind gust to 86 mph in their backyard in Westford.  Farther to the northeast, a tree was reported down on Forrest Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Circuit Avenue, Narragansett Avenue, and Kennebec Avenue was flooded.  An officer was on scene to assist motorists.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface low pressure (and an upper level low) passed just south of New England.  At the same time, a strong upper level short wave was passing to our north and a strong backdoor cold front was moving southward into northeastern Massachusetts.  A mid-level deformation zone set up over southeastern MA, which allowed an area of heavy rain to persist for several hours over Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket, producing some flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor street flooding was reported in downtown Nantucket with water up to sidewalks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot, humid conditions prevailed across the region.  Without much atmospheric forcing, it took a sea breeze boundary to set off strong thunderstorms, which became severe in eastern Massachusetts during the afternoon hours.  Localized flooding also occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Flash Flood emergency occurred, with considerable damage in the vicinity of Norwood Hospital. Severe flooding, more than 4 feet deep, occurred in the basement of the hospital. The entire pharmacy inventory was destroyed. One hundred patients had to be evacuated. Numerous cars were submerged in the parking lot, which, albeit, is in a 'bowl' not designed with flooding in mind. Damage to the hospital was estimated at $20,000,000. In addition, emergency management officials said that approximately 250 homes suffered flood damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level short wave trough combined with an approaching cold front and a warm, humid environment to produce severe thunderstorms and flash flooding across MA and northern RI during the afternoon and evening hours.  A Flash Flood Emergency occurred in the Norwood, MA area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime size hail was reported on Nantucket.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level cold pool provided the instability for scattered severe thunderstorms, with large hail and damaging winds in western Massachusetts and northern Connecticut during the mid-afternoon hours.  Franklin County, MA was particularly hard-hit by damaging winds.  Also, wind shear helped trigger some near-severe storms with hail and heavy rain in southeast Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 200-foot long tobacco barn, located where Long Plain Road becomes Straits Road, collapsed and was considered a complete loss from strong downburst winds, estimated around 70 mph.  The barn had shifted toward the south during the storm, causing it to collapse.  Damage also occurred to a dump truck and trailer that were inside the barn, which has recently been used for storage, instead of tobacco, according to a Greenfield Recorder article.  Several other trees were downed near the location of the barn.  In addition, amateur radio operators reported a tree down on Webber Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level cold pool provided the instability for scattered severe thunderstorms, with large hail and damaging winds in western Massachusetts and northern Connecticut during the mid-afternoon hours.  Franklin County, MA was particularly hard-hit by damaging winds.  Also, wind shear helped trigger some near-severe storms with hail and heavy rain in southeast Massachusetts.

Strong westerly to northwesterly winds developed during the morning of the 1st behind a cold front. Wind gusts in the 40 to 50 mph range were recorded. The winds brought down trees and wires and resulted in isolated power outages.

Strong westerly to northwesterly winds developed during the morning of the 1st behind a cold front. Wind gusts in the 40 to 50 mph range were recorded. The winds brought down trees and wires and resulted in isolated power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11 AM EST a tree fell on a car on Wood Street in Hopkinton. At 12:10 PM EST a tree and wires fell on Pond Street in Hopkinton.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure center passing through New York State on January 1 brought strong west winds to Massachusetts on January 1.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11:10 AM EST a tree fell on Arnold Road in Sturbridge. At 11:15 AM EST a tree fell on wires on Beaver Street in Worcester.  At 11:15 AM EST a large tree fell on Blackstone Street in Blackstone. At 11:35 AM EST a tree fell on Leland Hill Road in Grafton. At 12:30 PM EST a tree fell on a car on Canal Street in Sutton.  At 2:33 PM EST a tree fell on Morrison Drive in Mendon.  At 10:53 AM EST an amateur radio operator estimated a wind gust of 53 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure center passing through New York State on January 1 brought strong west winds to Massachusetts on January 1.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11:15 AM EST a tree fell on wires on Crane Neck Street in West Newbury.

A mix of rain and freezing rain developed in the early morning hours of January 9th ahead of an occluded front. The mixed precipitation quickly changed to snow over the higher terrain as the front passed and cold air was drawn into western Massachusetts. Upslope snow continued over higher elevations through the day and into the night before ending on the morning of the 10th. Accumulating snow occurred mainly above 1500 feet where totals of 4 to 10 inches were observed.

A winter storm impacted western Massachusetts on January 19th and 20th. Low pressure formed over the lower Mississippi Valley and lifted northeast across the Tennessee Valley during the night of the 19th before moving along the Mason-Dixon line on the 20th. Strong rising motion occurred as southerly winds aloft transported moist air northward, which was lifted over the cold airmass in place over western Massachusetts. Snowfall broke out during the afternoon of the 19th, continuing heavy at times into the evening and overnight hours before ending during the morning of the 20th. The strong southerly flow brought above-freezing air aloft into the region, causing the snow to turn to sleet and freezing rain for a time around during the wee hours to the early morning of the 20th before turning back to snow. Snow and sleet totals ranged from around 6 inches around Pittsfield and Great Barrington to around 20 inches over the high terrain of the Berkshires. Ice accretion of up to 0.15 inches was recorded due to freezing rain.||Frigid temperatures followed the snow for Monday and Tuesday, January 21st-22nd, with wind chills falling to -20 to -40F. The cold weather prompted the closing of schools and the opening of warming shelters across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing System platform at Worcester Regional Airport reported wind chill values as low as 34 degrees below zero.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west to northwest winds trailing the January 20th storm drew cold air across Southern New England on January 21st and caused wind chill values of 25 below zero or colder in Central and Western Massachusetts.  The wind diminished during the afternoon and evening of of January 21st allowing wind chill values to become less extreme, in the teens below zero.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hubbard Avenue was closed at the railroad underpass due to flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a moderate to heavy snowfall event on January 19-20, a strong low pressure system tracking through southern Canada ushered in an unseasonably warm and moist airmass on January 24th. Temperatures surged into the 40s to mid-50s. Steady rainfall occurred during much of the 24th as a secondary low pressure system developed over the Mid- Atlantic and tracked into southern New England. One to three inches of rainfall occurred over western Massachusetts. The combination of the rainfall along with the mild temperatures melting some of the snow resulted in isolated poor drainage flooding.

Snow developed along a warm front and ahead of an upper level trough during the evening of the 29th, continuing past midnight before ending during the early morning hours of the 30th. Generally 3 to 6 inches of snow fell across western Massachusetts.

Snow developed along a warm front and ahead of an upper level trough during the evening of the 29th, continuing past midnight before ending during the early morning hours of the 30th. Generally 3 to 6 inches of snow fell across western Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to six inches of snow fell on Western Hampden County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the Plains and Great Lakes, then across Northern New England the night of January 29th.  This brought snow to areas of Massachusetts north and west of Boston. Areas to the south had rain. Snow squalls then brought damaging west winds, especially in southeast Massachusetts, on evening of January 30th.

An arctic cold front tracked through western Massachusetts during the afternoon of the 30th, accompanied by a heavy snow squall. Frigid air poured in behind this front along with strong westerly winds. Wind chills the morning of the 31st fell to 15 to 30 degrees below zero. The wind chills prompted many schools to close or delay opening.

An arctic airmass that had infiltrated the region during the last two days of January persisted into the morning of February 1st. Wind chills fell to 10 to 25 degrees below zero. The wind chills prompted many schools to close or delay opening.

Widespread rainfall fell across the region on Friday, February 8th, 2019 as a low pressure system and cold front moved through New York and western New England. Strong winds developed behind the cold front, resulting in scattered power outages into the morning of Saturday, February 9th, 2019. Peak wind gusts up to around 56 mph were recorded, resulting in approximately 4,000 customers without power.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:45 AM EST on the 9th the mesonet station on top of Mt. Tom in Holyoke reported a sustained wind of 46 mph. At 4:15 AM EST the same mesonet station reported a wind gust to 67 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weather system from the Midwest initially brought snow and ice to the region. The system swung a cold front through New England, followed by strong west to northwest winds from the afternoon of the 8th to the afternoon of the 9th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 4:45 AM EST on the 9th the CoOperative Program observer in Rowe reported a 16-inch pine tree and four utility poles down on Zoar Road in Rowe.  Roughly 900 people in Rowe and Heath suffered power outages as a result. An amateur radio operator in Plainfield, in northwest Hampshire county, reported a gust to 54 mph at 2:59 AM.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weather system from the Midwest initially brought snow and ice to the region. The system swung a cold front through New England, followed by strong west to northwest winds from the afternoon of the 8th to the afternoon of the 9th.

A winter storm brought widespread wintry precipitation to Massachusetts on Tuesday, February 12th through Wednesday, February 13th, 2019. Precipitation started out as snow but then quickly transitioned to a period of sleet and then freezing rain throughout the event. This mix of wintry precipitation resulted in hundreds of closings and delays. Strong winds followed, especially across the Berkshires, which led to power outages across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 7:42 AM EST an amateur radio operator in Sterling reported six-hundredths of an inch of ice on the ground.  There were no reports of damage, but normally such a coating would cause some transportation issues.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Midwest storm redeveloped along the Mid Atlantic coast on the 12th and moves past Southern New England by the morning of the 13th.  This storm brought up to 5.5 inches of snow and three-eighths inch of ice to Massachusetts.

Strong to damaging westerly winds developed over eastern New York and western New England on Sunday, February 24th into Monday, February 25th, in association with a deep low pressure system over the Canadian Maritimes. Gusts in excess of 50 mph were common across the area, with several sites recording gusts in excess of 60 mph. Gusts were measured as high as 69 mph near Adams, MA. Numerous power outages and downed trees occurred as a result of the winds.

A northern stream clipper low brought a widespread light to moderate snowfall to western Massachusetts Wednesday, February 27th into the morning of Thursday, February 28th, 2019. Snowfall totals ranged from around an inch in southwest Massachusetts to about 5 inches across the northern Berkshires. While the snowfall was limited, it fell during the evening commute on Wednesday, resulting in multiple car accidents across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm the developed over the southern states moved up the coast the night of the 3rd and passed offshore of Nantucket the  morning of the 4th.  The storm then moved off to the northeast.  This brought heavy snow to much of Southern New England.  Highest snowfall amounts occurred from Northeast Connecticut to Boston Massachusetts.

The storm then moved off to the northeast.  This brought heavy snow to much of Southern New England.  Highest snowfall amounts occurred from Northeast Connecticut to Boston Massachusetts.

Strong westerly winds developed behind a cold frontal boundary, with wind gusts ranging from 35 to 55 mph during the afternoon and evening hours of Wednesday, April 3rd, 2019. These strong wind gusts resulted in a few reports of fallen trees and power outages across the region.

Strong westerly winds developed behind a cold frontal boundary, with wind gusts ranging from 35 to 55 mph during the afternoon and evening hours of Wednesday, April 3rd, 2019. These strong wind gusts resulted in a few reports of fallen trees and power outages across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 10:02 PM EST, the Automated Surface Observation System (ASOS) platform at Hanscom Field in Bedford reported a wind gust to 54 mph.  From 4:30 PM EST to 10:10 PM EST, there were several reports of large trees down, some bringing down wires in the process. There were two reports of utility poles brought down.  These events occurred on Main Street in Acton, Totman Road in Lowell, Middlesex Turnpike in Billerica, four locations in Concord, and North Road in Carlisle.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Coastal low pressure formed off the Carolina coast on April 2, then moved up the coast and passed offshore of Massachusetts on April 3. Strong west winds followed the passage of the low during the afternoon and night of April 3.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 10:50 PM EST, an amateur radio operator reported a wind gust to 46 mph in Duxbury. At 9:50 PM EST a large tree was down on wires on High Street in Hanson.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Coastal low pressure formed off the Carolina coast on April 2, then moved up the coast and passed offshore of Massachusetts on April 3. Strong west winds followed the passage of the low during the afternoon and night of April 3.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 9:53 PM EST, the Automated Surface Observation System (ASOS) platform at Lawrence Municipal Airport reported a wind gust to 60 mph. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Coastal low pressure formed off the Carolina coast on April 2, then moved up the coast and passed offshore of Massachusetts on April 3. Strong west winds followed the passage of the low during the afternoon and night of April 3.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Coastal low pressure formed off the Carolina coast on April 2, then moved up the coast and passed offshore of Massachusetts on April 3. Strong west winds followed the passage of the low during the afternoon and night of April 3.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 5:22 AM EDT, wires were reported down on Tennis Road at Mill Street due to a lightning strike.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving up the St Lawrence Valley swung a pair of cold fronts through Massachusetts and Rhode Island, with one in the morning and the second in the afternoon. Wind Advisories were in effect for strong northwest gradient wind gusts to 40 to 50 mph, which knocked down trees and branches. Thunderstorms with some heavy downpours also occurred along each front but only a couple were considered to be severe based on enhanced wind signatures; the majority of the damage occurred from the gradient wind.

At 3:12 PM EST a tree was down on Old Bedford Road in Lincoln. At 4:18 PM EST a large tree was down on the Boston Post Road Bypass in Weston.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved northeast from the Ohio Valley, bringing strong gusty south winds and mild air to Southern New England on April 19.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brimfield Police reported ping pong ball size hail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southern New England was on the cool side of a frontal boundary. However, strong winds aloft and directional shear led to rotating thunderstorms in the mid-afternoon hours that moved from northern CT into central MA. Strong rotation prompted a few tornado warnings but with the circulation remained aloft presumably due to the cool surface temperatures. Large hail did fall, however.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Southwick Emergency Management Director reported trees and wires down on Rising Corner Road at 1252 AM EDT.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm formed overnight in the moist air mass out ahead of an approaching cold front.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed blocking the road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms developed along a strong cold front during the late evening of the 23rd, resulting in a couple of downed trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on South Main Street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms developed along a strong cold front during the late evening of the 23rd, resulting in a couple of downed trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Northfield, MA, two large trees were down on wires on West Northfield Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level short wave trough over the Great Lakes was approaching New England, along with its attendant cold front.  This triggered a severe thunderstorm in northwest Massachusetts during the afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported dime size hail in Lexington.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pool of very cold air aloft... -21C at 500 mb ...led to very unstable air across southern New England. Despite dry air at the surface, showers and thunderstorms developed. There were several reports of hail ranging from pea to dime size.  A few storms in eastern MA produced wind gusts as high as 47 mph, but no damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported dime size hail in Plymouth.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pool of very cold air aloft... -21C at 500 mb ...led to very unstable air across southern New England. Despite dry air at the surface, showers and thunderstorms developed. There were several reports of hail ranging from pea to dime size.  A few storms in eastern MA produced wind gusts as high as 47 mph, but no damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 2:10 PM EST, a member of the general public reported three-quarter inch diameter hail in Warren.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept east across Southern New England, bringing showers and thunderstorms during the mid to late afternoon.  Some thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging wind. Heavy downpours from thunderstorms also caused flooding of streets in Suffolk County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was struck and blown apart at a campground on Wendell Road in Franklin. Two individuals, one male and one female, who were approximately 100 yards away, were indirectly struck. They were sitting in front of their camper with a phone that was plugged in.  They were transported to the hospital but there were no significant injuries.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front advanced into a very moist, almost tropical air mass in place across southern New England. This produced a line of thunderstorms, some with torrential downpours that caused flooding.  Isolated but significant wind damage occurred in Longmeadow, MA from a wet microburst.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wet microburst occurred between 459 PM and 5 PM EDT in Longmeadow, MA. According to the Emergency Management Director, about 200 trees were downed. Damage cost about $400,000 to clean up. The damage began just west of Route 5 and was maximized in the section of town near Longmeadow Brook and Frank Smith Road. A few trees were down onto houses.  There were no injuries reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Swansea, MA, Route 6 at Old Fall River Road was flooded and impassable.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved  northward across southern New England overnight as low pressure moved into northern New England.  In addition, an approaching upper level short wave trough and surface cold front led to the development of heavy rain with embedded thunderstorms that caused some flooding in Massachusetts during the early morning hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused a road washout in the Pinehills section of Plymouth on Long Ridge Road near the intersection with Sacrifice Rock Road.  Rainfall totals of 5.69 inches were reported by a ham radio spotter in Plymouth. The Plymouth Airport recorded 5.32 inches of rain in just six hours.  Basement flooding was reported up to the furnace on Sandwich Street in Plymouth.  A portion of Route 3A (State Road) was closed due to flooding.  According to the Boston Globe, in Plymouth Harbor, an unoccupied boat sank in its mooring due to the weight of the water and several other vessels had to be pumped out.  No injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved  northward across southern New England overnight as low pressure moved into northern New England.  In addition, an approaching upper level short wave trough and surface cold front led to the development of heavy rain with embedded thunderstorms that caused some flooding in Massachusetts during the early morning hours.

A heat wave gripped western Massachusetts from July 19th through the 21st. Temperatures soared to the low 90s with dewpoints in the low to mid-70s. This resulted in heat index values in the 95 to 105 range in the warmest valleys. Saturday, July 20th was the hottest day for most areas. Due to the excessive heat, cooling centers were opened and pool hours were extended.||The hot and humid airmass provided fuel for thunderstorms that formed along the Lake Ontario shoreline during the late afternoon of the 20th. One storm advanced into Berkshire County in the evening, resulting in a report of wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed tree.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave gripped western Massachusetts from July 19th through the 21st. Temperatures soared to the low 90s with dewpoints in the low to mid-70s. This resulted in heat index values in the 95 to 105 range in the warmest valleys. Saturday, July 20th was the hottest day for most areas. Due to the excessive heat, cooling centers were opened and pool hours were extended.||The hot and humid airmass provided fuel for thunderstorms that formed along the Lake Ontario shoreline during the late afternoon of the 20th. One storm advanced into Berkshire County in the evening, resulting in a report of wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Fall River, Stafford Square was not passable due to flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked along a frontal boundary that was draped across CT, RI and southeast MA at night.  It was accompanied by heavy showers and a few severe thunderstorms, causing street flooding and wind damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In New Bedford, Acushnet Avenue at Wamsutta Street was flooded and impassable, with manhole covers popping off due to the flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In West Tisbury, two trees were down on Lamberts Cove Road.  One tree and wires were down on State Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep southerly flow of tropical moisture was in place over southeast MA with precipitable water values in excess of 2 inches on the south coast. A frontal wave along the coast provided strong low level convergence and that combined with upper divergence from the right entrance region of a 110 knot upper level jet to produce very severe weather for Cape Cod.  Three tornadoes occurred!  Prior to these, there had only been three recorded tornadoes since 1950.  Outside of the tornado area, damage surveys showed that strong microburst winds caused straight-line damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was down on wires on Barnstable Road. A large branch was down in front of a hotel on Pitchers Way. Wires were reported down on Scudder Avenue.  A tree was down on Ocean Avenue.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep southerly flow of tropical moisture was in place over southeast MA with precipitable water values in excess of 2 inches on the south coast. A frontal wave along the coast provided strong low level convergence and that combined with upper divergence from the right entrance region of a 110 knot upper level jet to produce very severe weather for Cape Cod.  Three tornadoes occurred!  Prior to these, there had only been three recorded tornadoes since 1950. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A waterspout moved onshore just west of Kalmus Beach in Barnstable, MA at 1157 AM EDT (1057 AM EST). Winds gusted to 91 mph at a mesonet observation site at Kalmus. They had shifted from southeast to west-northwest with the passage of the tornado.  The tornado continued moving northeastward at about 35 mph. The damage was discontinuous but where the tornado touched down, the damage was quite significant, with winds estimated as high as 110 mph. ||The roof of a motel on the south side of Main Street in West Yarmouth was completely peeled off.  Additional significant tornado damage occurred just southwest of the Dennis-Yarmouth Regional High School, particularly along Hazelmoor Road from Violet Glen Road to Vine Brook Road.  Dozens of large trees were uprooted and a few were snapped off.  Another house had a hole in the roof from a fallen tree.||The tornado then lifted.  However, severe straight-line wind damage was observed from West Dennis eastward to West Harwich.  Numerous large trees were uprooted, consistent with 90 mph gusts or greater.||Amazingly, no injuries were reported with the storm.  Cleanup of roads cost approximately $434,000 in Yarmouth. That does not count damage to homes or private claims.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep southerly flow of tropical moisture was in place over southeast MA with precipitable water values in excess of 2 inches on the south coast. A frontal wave along the coast provided strong low level convergence and that combined with upper divergence from the right entrance region of a 110 knot upper level jet to produce very severe weather for Cape Cod.  Three tornadoes occurred!  Prior to these, there had only been three recorded tornadoes since 1950.  Outside of the tornado area, damage surveys showed that strong microburst winds caused straight-line damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief and narrow tornado occurred in West Yarmouth and was on the ground at the very same time as another tornado was moving toward South Yarmouth!||The tornado touched down on Yacht Avenue and Schooner Street in West Yarmouth and traveled east approximately one-quarter mile before lifting on Egg Harbor Road, just after Pine Cone Drive.  The path width was approximately 50 yards.  Numerous pine trees were snapped near their bases.  Tree tops appeared twisted.  Residents reported seeing swirling motion.  NWS Doppler Radar showed a tornado debris signature with this storm, indicating that some trees and branches were lofted into the air.  This tornado was only on the ground for one minute, between noon and 1201 PM EDT (1100 and 1101 AM EST).  It lifted as it approached the south end of the Bass River.||Although a brief and very shallow waterspout was observed over the southern part of the Bass River, the damage in West Dennis just to the east of Wrinkle Point was considered to be from strong straight line downburst winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Hyannis, a tree was down on Gosnold Street at Old Colony Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS survey team determined that although a weak, shallow waterspout was observed over the southern end of the Bass River, the damage observed in West Dennis was from straight-line microburst winds, estimated at 90+ mph. Media and amateur radio contributed to the following reports, as well.  Numerous trees and wires were snapped or downed at Wrinkle Point.  Trees and wires were down on Loring Avenue. Wires were down on Corporation Road.  Trees, wires, and a utility pole were down on Pleasant Street.  Wires were down on a car on Depot Street at Vester Drive.  Power lines were down on Old Wharf Road.  Trees down on Sunset Drive.  There were many others. State Emergency Management reported that the cost to Dennis just for cleaning up the roads was a whopping $860,000.  Total estimates were approximately triple that figure, when accounting for individual homeowner and business claims.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep southerly flow of tropical moisture was in place over southeast MA with precipitable water values in excess of 2 inches on the south coast. A frontal wave along the coast provided strong low level convergence and that combined with upper divergence from the right entrance region of a 110 knot upper level jet to produce very severe weather for Cape Cod.  Three tornadoes occurred!  Prior to these, there had only been three recorded tornadoes since 1950.  Outside of the tornado area, damage surveys showed that strong microburst winds caused straight-line damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the Osterville section of Barnstable, two small boats were flipped over in West Bay. A tree was down on wires on Scudder Road.  Several large trees and many large branches were down on Wianno Avenue.  Storm survey determined this wind damage to be straight-line.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep southerly flow of tropical moisture was in place over southeast MA with precipitable water values in excess of 2 inches on the south coast. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The same supercell storm that produced the Barnstable-Yarmouth tornado went on to touch down again near the center of Harwich, MA at 1210 PM EDT (1110 AM EST). The initial touchdown was just east of Harwich Elementary School, just south of Parallel Street.  It moved northeast through Harwich Center, passing just south of a golf course, and lifted in East Harwich in the Vicinity of Queen Anne Road.  At least 150 hardwood trees were either uprooted or snapped.  A few homes also had shingles that were ripped off.  Wind gusts were estimated as high as 110 mph, which is on the high end of the Enhanced Fujita EF-1 ranking.  Harwich spent $1.2 million on cleanup of roads.  That figure is estimated to be one-third of the total costs, when individual homeowner claims are taken into account.||The tornado then lifted.  However, severe straight-line wind damage was observed in Chatham.  Numerous large trees were uprooted, consistent with 90 mph gusts or greater.

Three tornadoes occurred!  Prior to these, there had only been three recorded tornadoes since 1950.  Outside of the tornado area, damage surveys showed that strong microburst winds caused straight-line damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Brewster, a large tree was down on Stony Brook Road. A tree and power lines were down on Run Hill Road.  Numerous other trees were down throughout the town.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep southerly flow of tropical moisture was in place over southeast MA with precipitable water values in excess of 2 inches on the south coast. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Chatham, a NWS survey found numerous large trees uprooted, consistent with 90+ mph microburst straight line winds, which is what remained after the Harwich tornado lifted. Two utility poles were leaning on Morris Island Road with one snapped in half and wires hanging low to the ground.  A mesonet site reported a gust to 85 mph at 1115 AM EST (1215 PM EDT). Emergency management cited $426,000 in costs for the town to clean debris from roadways.  Total damage estimates are much higher, accounting for individual homeowner and business claims.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot, humid weather regime was in place across southern New England.  A weak, subtle upper level shortwave passing through in the afternoon hours helped trigger an isolated severe thunderstorm in northwest Massachusetts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms crossed Massachusetts ahead of a cold front and produced widespread wind damage, including two microbursts at Logan International Airport in Boston where wind gusts of 68 MPH and 73 MPH were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 63 mph was recorded at Mt. Tom.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moving across southern New England triggered severe thunderstorms with wind damage across western portions of southern New England from the mid afternoon hours and through the evening.  Another band of thunderstorms moved in from the southwest overnight, progressing to the coast before daybreak, causing some additional wind damage and some flooding.

An upper level disturbance moved through the region ahead of a surface cold front, which sparked off strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours of Thursday, August 8th, 2019. As a result, multiple trees and wires were downed across the region.

The first frost and freeze of the season fell upon the area during the early morning hours of Saturday, October 5th, 2019. Low temperatures ranged from the mid 20s to low 30s.
The first frost and freeze of the season fell upon the area during the early morning hours of Saturday, October 5th, 2019. Low temperatures ranged from the mid 20s to low 30s.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Wellfleet, a CWOP site measured a gust to 60 mph at 501 PM EST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ocean storm well to the south and southeast of Nantucket combined with strong high pressure over the Canadian maritime provinces to create a prolonged period of strong to damaging winds across Massachusetts and Rhode Island.  The ocean storm was briefly named Subtropical Storm Melissa.

A strengthening low pressure system and cold front brought a widespread soaking rainfall to the region from the afternoon hours of Wednesday, October 16th through the morning of Thursday, October 17th, 2019. Strong winds preceded the cold frontal passage. Fortunately, only minor flooding occurred due to dry antecedent conditions.

A strengthening low pressure system and cold front brought a widespread soaking rainfall to the region from the afternoon hours of Wednesday, October 16th through the morning of Thursday, October 17th, 2019. Strong winds preceded the cold frontal passage. Fortunately, only minor flooding occurred due to dry antecedent conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In New Bedford, Cove Road was closed from Stapleton Street to County Street, due to a reported 2.5 feet of flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving from Pennsylvania to the southern New England coast produced a widespread soaking rainfall.  One to three inches of rain fell in eastern MA, but a swath of three to four inches fell in southern Bristol County, MA, which led to some street flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Morrissey Boulevard at Freeport Street and the UMass-Boston entrance was flooded and impassable due to coastal flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High astronomical tides, along with onshore flow and rough seas led to splashover and minor coastal flooding around the time of the late morning high tide in eastern Massachusetts.

A strengthening low pressure system moving from Ohio to Lake Ontario drew anomalous warmth and moisture northward on Halloween, with temperatures surging into the 60s and 70s over western New England. Moderate rainfall and strong winds developed across the region as a result of this low pressure system. Total rainfall of half an inch up to one and a half inches fell in western Massachusetts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 726 PM EST, a mesonet station in Milton, MA recorded a wind gust to 61 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved quickly across the region late on the 31st.  Ahead of the front it was a warm and very windy night, with many downed trees and power lines from strong south-southwest wind gusts. A 'fine line' of showers and isolated thunderstorms also helped mix down very strong winds from aloft.  The damaging winds continued into the early morning on Nov. 1.

A strengthening low pressure system moving from Ohio to Lake Ontario drew anomalous warmth and moisture northward on Halloween, with temperatures surging into the 60s and 70s over western New England. Moderate rainfall and strong winds developed across the region as a result of this low pressure system. Winds gusted as high as 53 mph, and half an inch to one and a half inches of rain fell in western Massachusetts.

Widespread precipitation developed in association with a coastal low pressure system during the early morning hours of the 24th. While lower elevations saw mainly rain, some of the higher elevations in the Berkshires saw a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain changing to snow. Accumulations were generally light, but the wintry precipitation resulted in slippery travel conditions with some accidents reported. The wintry precipitation ended in the evening of the 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported wind gusts of 58 mph in Truro at 846 PM EST and 58 mph in Wellfleet at 857 PM EST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying storm system over the Cape Cod Canal area in the late afternoon moved northeast in the evening.  Strong pressure rises behind the departing storm led to wind gusts of 40 to 58 mph across eastern Massachusetts.  There were two reports meeting high wind criteria on outer Cape Cod.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Methuen, strong winds knocked down wires and several power poles on Jackson Street and Pleasant Valley Street in the area of Marston Corners, causing power outages.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure pulled east of New England.  Strong northwest winds gusted to 35-45 mph across the region, with a few 45-53 mph gusts reported in Rhode Island and southeast Massachusetts.

A major winter storm impacted eastern New York and western New England December 1-3, 2019. Snowfall began during the late morning and early afternoon of the 1st ahead of a weakening low pressure system approaching from the western Great Lakes. As the primary low pressure system weakened, it transferred its energy to a coastal low, which strengthened as it remained nearly stationary for much of the 2nd. This allowed snow to continue to accumulate throughout the day. As the low finally pulled away late on the 2nd into the early morning hours of the 3rd, one final heavy snow band crossed the area before the snow finally pulled out prior to daybreak on the 3rd.||Storm total snowfall amounts were heaviest across portions of eastern New York into the Berkshires, where totals of 18-28 were common. Many schools were closed for two consecutive days, and numerous flights were delayed or cancelled. Speed restrictions were also placed on area interstate highways. Amounts of 8-18 were common elsewhere.

A major winter storm impacted eastern New York and western New England December 1-3, 2019. Snowfall began during the late morning and early afternoon of the 1st ahead of a weakening low pressure system approaching from the western Great Lakes. As the primary low pressure system weakened, it transferred its energy to a coastal low, which strengthened as it remained nearly stationary for much of the 2nd. This allowed snow to continue to accumulate throughout the day. As the low finally pulled away late on the 2nd into the early morning hours of the 3rd, one final heavy snow band crossed the area before the snow finally pulled out prior to daybreak on the 3rd.||Storm total snowfall amounts were heaviest across portions of eastern New York into the Berkshires, where totals of 18-28 were common. Many schools were closed for two consecutive days, and numerous flights were delayed or cancelled. Speed restrictions were also placed on area interstate highways. Amounts of 8-18 were common elsewhere.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Final snow totals ranged from 18 to 22 inches of snow. A member of the public reported 22.5 inches of snow in Plainfield and a member of the media reported 22 inches of snow in Middlefield.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system slowly moved across southeast Massachusetts and into the Gulf of Maine during this period.  One to two feet of snow fell in much of western and northern Massachusetts by the morning of December 3.  Rain changed to snow on December 2 in eastern Massachusetts.  An initial thump of snow, accompanied by some thunder, moved across central portions on the evening of December 1. Many areas had a lull on Dec. 2, except in northwest Massachusetts, where snow continued.  Another heavy snow band formed overnight on December 2-3 in Hampden County, MA and Hartford County, CT.  Snow lingered well into the afternoon of December 3 in eastern MA before the whole system exited.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Final snow totals ranged from 20 to 24 inches in western Franklin county. A Co-op observer in East Hawley reported 24 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3 AM EST, a mesonet site at Siasconset recorded a wind gust to 58 mph. It then hit 61 mph at 415 AM EST and gusted again to 60 mph at 516 AM EST.  In the town of Nantucket, an amateur radio observer measured a wind gust to 63 mph at 316 AM EST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 62 mph was reported by an amateur radio operator in Nantucket at 1016 AM.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure passed northwest of southern New England during the early morning with gusty southeast winds. This was followed by a second southerly low level jet, with winds of 80-90 knots at 925 mb.  Despite a strong low level inversion, winds gusted past 60 mph at Nantucket in the late morning.
Strong winds developed as a strengthening low pressure system lifted out of the area. These strong winds resulted in power outages across portions of western New England.

A progressive storm system approached the area from the southwest late Monday night, spreading a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain across western Massachusetts. The wintry mix came to an end late Tuesday evening. Snow and sleet totals across northern Berkshire county of up to 6 inches occurred, whereas totals across southern Berkshire county were 3 inches or less.

The wintry mix came to an end late Tuesday evening. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Co-Operative Observer snowfall totals in western Franklin County reached 7.4 inches at Rowe and 5.6 inches in East Hawley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure passed south of New England and created a mixed bag of precipitation.  In southeast Massachusetts, light snow was followed by 0.1 to 0.25 of freezing rain.  In northern and western Massachusetts, 1 to 4 inches of snow fell.  The only exception was in northwestern Franklin County, where an average of 6 inches of snow was reported.

In the wake of an arctic frontal boundary, dangerously cold air filtered into the region. This arctic air combined with northerly winds, resulted in wind chills ranging from 10 degrees to 25 degrees below zero.

In the wake of an arctic frontal boundary, dangerously cold air filtered into the region. This arctic air combined with northerly winds, resulted in wind chills ranging from 10 degrees to 25 degrees below zero.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site atop Mount Tom recorded a wind gust to 62 mph at 129 AM.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong Arctic cold front passed through in the late evening of Dec. 18th.  It was followed by a brief period of high wind gusts shortly after midnight on Dec. 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site at Chapin Beach in Dennis, MA recorded a wind gust to 63 mph at 307 AM.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong Arctic cold front passed through in the late evening of Dec. 18th.  It was followed by a brief period of high wind gusts shortly after midnight on Dec. 19th.

A complex winter storm brought a mix of rain, snow, sleet and freezing rain to the region from the evening of Sunday, December 29th, lingering through the morning of Tuesday, December 31st, 2019. Heavy accumulations of ice impacted portions of western Massachusetts during this time frame. There were hundreds of people without power due to a combination of icy conditions and strong winds bringing down trees and power lines.

A complex winter storm brought a mix of rain, snow, sleet and freezing rain to the region from the evening of Sunday, December 29th, lingering through the morning of Tuesday, December 31st, 2019. Heavy accumulations of ice impacted portions of western Massachusetts during this time frame. There were hundreds of people without power due to a combination of icy conditions and strong winds bringing down trees and power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One-half inch of ice accretion was reported in Rowe.  At 1044 AM in Ashfield, amateur radio operators reported wires downed and sparking on Hawley Road across from the Water Department shed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system over the Great Lakes drew in moisture across southern New England, where cold air remained in place at the higher elevations.  This led to ice storm conditions on the 30th in a narrow region along the immediate east slopes of the Berkshires, where 0.5 to 0.75 inches of ice was observed.  Lesser amounts occurred in northern Worcester County. There was also some light snow and sleet, mainly north of the Mass Pike.  Weaker low pressure developed south of Long Island on the 31st, which prolonged light precipitation. ||Elevated instability during the afternoon of the 30th led to thunderstorms tracking across the Poconos, eastern NY, and into northern CT and western and central MA. One of these storms became severe, producing quarter-size hail in Southwick and Westfield, MA (Hampden County) - very unusual for the end of December.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately 0.10 to 0.25 of ice accretion occurred in northwesternmost Middlesex County.  At 855 AM in Ashby, a portion of a tree was reported down between Piper and Mayo Roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow averaged close to 6 inches in western Hampshire County, but ranged all the way from 1 to 9.5 inches, with the highest amounts in the immediate east slopes of the Berkshires.  Some specific amounts included 9.5 inches in Cummington (amateur radio), 8.0 inches in Plainfield (CoCoRaHS), 7.0 inches in Middlefield (broadcast media), 2.0 inches in Westhampton (CoCoRaHS), and 1.0 inches in Williamsburg (CoCoRaHS).
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure in the Ohio Valley spawned a secondary low pressure system off the mid-Atlantic coast, which moved northward into northern New England. It brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to much of Massachusetts, but in the highest terrain of western Franklin and Hampshire Counties, it was cold enough for 6 to 10 inches of snow to pile up during the overnight and early morning hours.  The heavy, wet snow downed some trees and wires in Franklin County.  Strong winds occurred in eastern Massachusetts, with gusts to 50 to 55 mph and a sustained wind generally of 30 to 40 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow averaged 6 inches across western Franklin County, but ranged from 3 to 10 inches, highest in the immediate higher slopes of the Berkshires.  Specific amounts included 10.0 inches in East Hawley (CoOp Observer), 8.5 inches in Ashfield (public), 8.3 inches in Heath (amateur radio), 8.2 inches in Rowe (Co-Op Observer), 4.6 inches in Colrain (CoCoRaHS), 4.0 inches in Shelburne Falls (amateur radio), 3.1 inches in Conway (CoCoRaHS), and 3.0 inches in Leyden (amateur radio).  In Colrain at 809 AM EST, power lines were down on Adamsville Road due to the weight of the wet snow.  In Shelburne at 925 AM EST, wires were down on Route 2 due to heavy, wet snow.  In Heath at 958 AM EST, a tree was down on Burnt Hill Road due to the heavy, wet snow.  In Charlemont at 1018 AM EST, a tree and wires were down on West Oxbow Road due to the weight of the wet snow.

A storm system brought a mix of rain and snow to western Massachusetts from early Saturday, January 16th through the morning of Sunday, January 17th, 2021. Snow was mainly confined to the higher elevations in Northern Berkshire county where up to 13 inches fell. Southern Berkshire county saw mainly rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 940 AM EST, an UrbaNet station in 1 mile north of Marblehead recorded a sustained wind of 43 mph.

A low pressure system brought a light to moderate snowfall to western Massachusetts from the morning hours of Tuesday, January 26th into the morning of Wednesday, January 27th, 2021. Snowfall totals ranged from 3 to about 6 across Berkshire county. Some of the steadier snowfall impacted the Tuesday evening commute.

Snowfall totals ranged from 3 to about 6 across Berkshire county. Some of the steadier snowfall impacted the Tuesday evening commute.

A combination of an arctic airmass and gusty winds resulted in dangerously cold wind chills across west Massachusetts the night of January 28th into January 29th, 2021. Low temperatures ranged from 7 degrees below zero up to 6 degrees above zero in Berkshire county. Wind chill values ranged from 32 degrees below zero up to 0 degrees in Berkshire county.

A combination of an arctic airmass and winds resulted in low cold wind chills across west Massachusetts the night of January 29th into January 30th, 2021. Low temperatures ranged from 12 degrees below zero up to 3 degrees above zero in Berkshire county. Wind chill values ranged from 25 degrees below zero up to 1 degree below zero.

A combination of an arctic airmass and winds resulted in low cold wind chills across west Massachusetts the night of January 29th into January 30th, 2021. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts averaged 4 to 8 inches. A coastal front created a sharp gradient from west to east, reaching from 4 inches in the eastern parts of Qunicy and Weymouth to 14.2 inches atop Blue Hill in Milton. At 551 AM on the 2nd, the ASOS at the Blue Hill Observatory (KMQE) reported a gust to 53 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid level trough over the Appalachians produced a secondary surface low pressure near the mid-Atlantic coast. High pressure over Hudson Bay allowed low level cold air to stay in place initially. Most of the region received 8 to 12 inches of snow, but a coastal front kept accumulations down in southeast and extreme eastern Massachusetts. This storm also produced strong winds and minor coastal flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A coastal front caused a sharp gradient in the snowfall totals across southeast Middlesex County. Snowfall totals ranged from as little as 4 inches near Cambridge to as much as 18.2 inches in Winchester. At 1215 AM EST in Watertown a large tree was down due to the weight of snow on Standish Road.

Moderate to heavy snow developed to the northwest of a slow-moving coastal low on February 1st. The snow was light initially during the morning hours of the 1st, but an area of heavy snow expanded northwestward during the afternoon and evening, with snowfall rates of one to three inches per hour observed at times. The snow moved north of the region by the wee hours of the 2nd.  Storm totals ranged from 10 to 18 inches. The snow prompted the governor to issue speed limit restrictions and a ban on tractor trailers from the Mass Pike. There were numerous school closures and delays. Key impacts: transportation delays, school closures.

At 1115 PM EST in Dennisport a tree, wires, and a utility pole were down on Siasconset Ave. At 1124 PM in Harwich a tree was down on Lovers Lane. According to an article by WCVB-TV 5 in Boston, coastal erosion left several homes along Salt Marsh Road in Sandwich so heavily damaged that they have been condemned, including one that's foundation appeared to collapse after the ground beneath it was washed away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system underwent rapid intensification near the Benchmark of 40N/70W as it tracked quickly northeastward.  A particularly heavy snow band formed from northeast Connecticut to the Metro-West Boston area.  During the afternoon, 3 to 4 inch per hour snowfall rates occurred in this band.  It was a quick-hitting storm, starting around noon and ending in the early evening.

Light snow developed over western Massachusetts on the 9th, mainly during the morning and afternoon, with two to five inches reported. The snow caused some schools to cancel or go virtual with classes. The governor issued speed and tractor trailer restrictions on the Mass Pike.  Key impacts: school closures, transportation delays.

Light snow developed over western Massachusetts on the 9th, mainly during the morning and afternoon, with two to five inches reported. The snow caused some schools to cancel or go virtual with classes. The governor issued speed and tractor trailer restrictions on the Mass Pike.  Key impacts: school closures, transportation delays.

Light snow moved into portions of western Massachusetts during the late evening of the 15th, and turned to freezing rain through the night before ending around sunrise on the 16th. Flat ice accretion of a tenth to a half an inch impacted western Massachusetts along with up to two inches of snow. The freezing rain resulted in icy roads with a few crashes reported. Key impacts: traffic accidents.

Flat ice accretion of a tenth to a half an inch impacted western Massachusetts along with up to two inches of snow. The freezing rain resulted in icy roads with a few crashes reported. Key impacts: traffic accidents.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 60 mph was recorded at both the Harriman-and-West and Pittsfield Municipal airports.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across the region on Monday, March 1 advecting in a much colder air mass along with a prolonged period of strong to locally damaging winds which continued into the early part of Tuesday, March 2. Wind gusts between 40 and 60 mph were common across the region, which led to some downed trees and power lines and isolated power outages.||Colder air continued to filter into the region during the overnight and early morning hours of March 2 with low temperatures mainly in the single digits. This, combined with continued gusty winds, led to wind chill values falling to between 15 and 22 degrees below zero in some areas.||Key impacts: tree damage, power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds resulted in downed tree limbs and some power outages across southern Berkshire County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across the region on Monday, March 1 advecting in a much colder air mass along with a prolonged period of strong to locally damaging winds which continued into the early part of Tuesday, March 2. Wind gusts between 40 and 60 mph were common across the region, which led to some downed trees and power lines and isolated power outages.||Colder air continued to filter into the region during the overnight and early morning hours of March 2 with low temperatures mainly in the single digits. This, combined with continued gusty winds, led to wind chill values falling to between 15 and 22 degrees below zero in some areas.||Key impacts: tree damage, power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 407 PM EST on March 1, a mesonet site atop Mt. Tom recorded a wind gust to 62 mph and at 412 AM EST on March 2, it gusted to 78 mph.  Other wind gusts included 61 mph on the ASOS at Westfield-Barnes Airport (KBAF) at 453 AM EST on the 2nd and 56 mph at Westover Airport (KCEF) at 356 AM EST on the 2nd.  In Wilbraham at 1045 PM EST, a 50-foot spruce tree was down on Stony Hill Road.  Also, another tree was down on Crane Hill Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front moved through southern New England on the afternoon of March 1st.  It was followed by very strong/damaging west-northwest winds, which continued through much of the night and into the early morning hours on March 2nd.  There were many reports of downed trees and at one point, more than 60,000 customers were without power in Massachusetts.

A strong cold front moved across the region on Monday, March 1 advecting in a much colder air mass along with a prolonged period of strong to locally damaging winds which continued into the early part of Tuesday, March 2. Wind gusts between 40 and 60 mph were common across the region, which led to some downed trees and power lines and isolated power outages.||Colder air continued to filter into the region during the overnight and early morning hours of March 2 with low temperatures mainly in the single digits. This, combined with continued gusty winds, led to wind chill values falling to between 15 and 22 degrees below zero in some areas.||Key impacts: tree damage, power outages.

In Dudley at 1020 PM EST, a large tree was down on Fairview Avenue.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the wake of an arctic cold front, strong northwest winds occurred across southern New England during the evening of March 12th and the overnight hours on March 13th.  These winds caused scattered damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sadly, winds gusting to around 50 mph, knocked down a rotted tree, which directly hit a 1-year-old baby, who his father was holding in the front yard of his house.  The father only had scratches, but the baby was taken to a hospital and he died the next day.
